title: Introduction to Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Surveys historical and contemporary approaches to the scientific study of behavior and mental processes. Introduces students to the biological bases of sensation, perception, and behavior; human development and learning; sociocultural and individual influences on behavior and personality; human information processing; and the assessment and treatment of psychopathology.

title: Methods of Social Research
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Theoretical and practical introduction to the planning, conducting, and reporting of research in the social sciences. Psychology 1980, Statistics 100, or the equivalent.

title: Methods of Social Research
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Theoretical and practical introduction to planning, conducting, reporting, and evaluating research in the social sciences. Psychology 1980, or Statistics 100, or equivalent.

title: Methods of Social Research
subject: PSY

title: Human Nature
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Theories of human nature and their implications. Is there a human nature? If so, what is it? What competing images of humanity are found in religion, art forms, social and political theories, and psychology, biology, and neuroscience? Can we change what we are? Is law a lever of behavior modification with a theory of human nature as its fulcrum? How might new approaches to human nature affect the organization of the university? Offered jointly with the Law School as 38220-1/38220-32.

title: The Psychology of Well-being
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course will critically examine the nature of well-being, happiness and the good life. This course will cover a range of topics such as: optimal functioning, strengths, values, interests, mindfulness, physical health, and happiness. Through group and class discussions, involved exercises, projects, videos, and review of journal articles, students will: (i) gain an understanding of well-being related concepts, (ii) learn to think critically and analytically about issues related to positive psychology, (iii) experience the effects of applying well-being related principles on your own personal growth, (iv) propose an intervention to bring about change in a well-being related behavior. SLS-20 and one from PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS 15.

title: Human Nature
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Theories of human nature and their implications. Is there a human nature? If so, what is it? What competing images of humanity are found in religion, art forms, social and political theories, and psychology, biology, and neuroscience? Can we change what we are? Is law a lever of behavior modification with a theory of human nature as its fulcrum? How might new approaches to human nature affect the organization of the university? Jointly offered with the Law School as 38220-1/38220-32.

title: History of Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A study of the organization of psychology in the late 19th and 20th centuries. Early psychologists_James, Hall, Dewey, Titchener, and Thorndike_initiate research programs in sensation and perception, the study of exceptional mental states, and several forms of educational psychology. Psychologies of personal and social design emerge, centering at first on the naturalistic programs of the ^'^'brass instrument laboratories'' and theoretical behaviorism, but more and more giving a place to cognitive, developmental, personality, clinical, and social programs.

Graduate students are encouraged to enroll.

title: Evolving Morality: From Primordial Soup to Superintelligent Machines
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the evolution of morality on Earth, from its origins in the biology of unthinking cooperative organisms, through the psychology of intelligent cooperative primates, and into a future inhabited by machines that may be more intelligent and better organized than humans. We begin with foundational scientific questions: What is morality? Where does it come from, and what does it do? How is it implemented in our brains? We then apply our scientific understanding of morality to foundational moral and political questions: How should human societies be organized? How should we resolve the moral questions that divide us? Finally, we consider the distinctive moral challenges posed by increasingly powerful artificial intelligence. Can machines (such as self-driving cars and military “drones”) be programmed to behave morally? Will artificial intelligence displace human labor? If so, how can we adapt? Could machines displace humans entirely? If so, how can we stay in control? If machines do take over, will they be our conquerors or our children?

title: The Psychology of Addiction: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of addiction. Emphasis on biological and behavioral experimental literature, with some attention to epidemiological, historical, and biographical literature. A course in psychology or behavioral biology.

title: Morality and Taboo
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Psychological and legal aspects of morality, the moral sense, taboo, dangerous ideas, and related topics. Does morality come from social conventions, innate intuitions, divine decree, platonic reality, or some combination? Can it ever be immoral to evaluate controversial ideas, such as ones about torture, innate group differences, the environment, infanticide, or the legalization of distasteful but victimless practices? When is it rational, or moral, to choose to be ignorant?

title: The Psychology of Addiction
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Why are certain drugs addictive? A survey of research and theory on drug addiction. Emphasis on biological and behavioral experimental studies, but lectures and readings also include epidemiological, historical, and biographical materials. Course ends with discussion of implications of scientific research for public policy on control of addictive drugs. A course in psychology (e.g., Psychology 11) or behavioral biology.

title: The Psychology of Addiction: Seminar

courseDescriptionLong: An examination of addiction. Emphasis on biological and behavioral experimental literature, with some attention to epidemiological, historical, and biographical literature. A course in psychology or behavioral biology.

title: The Psychology of Addiction
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A survey of theory and research on drug addiction. Reading is drawn primarily, but not exclusively, from experimental and epidemiological research. Other sources include biographies of drug users and essays on policy, treatment, and the history of nonmedical drug use. A course in psychology (e.g., Psychology 11) or behavioral biology.

title: Morality and Taboo
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Psychological and legal aspects of morality, the moral sense, taboo, dangerous ideas, and related topics. Does morality come from social conventions, innate intuitions, divine decree, platonic reality, or some combination? Can it ever be immoral to evaluate controversial ideas, such as ones about torture, innate group differences, the environment, infanticide, or the legalization of distasteful but victimless practices? When is it rational, or moral, to choose to be ignorant?

title: Psychology of Sport
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the field of sport psychology. An overview of theory and practice related to contemporary issues in the field, including personality and performance, motivation, attention control, leadership styles, stress/arousal/anxiety, athletic counseling, performance enhancement techniques and positive psychology and sport performance. PSY 1, Introductory Psychology, or permission of instructor.

title: Psychology of Sport
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the field of sport psychology. An overview of theory and practice related to contemporary issues in the field, including personality and performance, motivation, attention control, leadership styles, stress/arousal/anxiety, athletic counseling, performance enhancement techniques and positive psychology and sport performance. PSY 1, Introductory Psychology, or permission of instructor.

title: Psychology of Sport
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the field of sport psychology. An overview of theory and practice related to contemporary issues in the field, including personality and performance, motivation, attention control, leadership styles, stress/arousal/anxiety, athletic counseling, performance enhancement techniques and positive psychology and sport performance. PSY 1, Introductory Psychology, or permission of instructor.

title: Psychology of Sport
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to sport psychology research, theory and practice. Topics include: history of sport psychology, personality and performance, motivation, attention control, leadership styles, coaching, team performance, stress/arousal/anxiety, aggression, testing and performance enhancement techniques. We will also discuss the application of psychology of sport to injury, eating disorders, drug use and burnout.

title: Consumable Science
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: We live in a consumer society. Scientists have missed an opportunity to turn their findings into consumable morsels. This course has two goals. First, we will grapple with the most controversial scientific problems today--stem cells, evolution, neuroethics, genetic enhancements--and attempt to turn the complexities into simple take home messages. Second, we will create a marketing campaign converting these facts into consumable products, digestible by the citizens of Boston and beyond. Open to both graduate and undergraduate students. Any of the following courses LS1a, 1b, PSY 13, B29, B61, or Introduction to Psychology, can serve as a prerequisite.

title: Health Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course will examine psychological and physical health from the perspective of Positive Psychology. A major focus will be on mindfulness theory and its relationship to stress/coping; illness/wellness; decision-making; placebos. The medical model, the bio social model, and a unified mind/body model will be compared to examine their relationship to achieving resilience.

title: Health:  A Positive Psychology Perspective
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Why does it seem that some people are so resilient and content?  This course looks at psychological and physical health from the perspective of Positive Psychology. The major focus will be on mindfulness theory and its relationship to stress/coping; illness/wellness; decision-making; and placebos. The medical model, the biosocial model, and a unified mind-body model will be compared to examine their role in becoming mindful and thus healthier, happier and less stressed.

title: Health Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course will examine psychological and physical health and the relationship between them. Research from mindfulness theory, mind/body studies, and positive psychology will be discussed along with research on stress, medical decision-making, behavioral medicine and social psychological theories that are pertinent to health. SLS-20 or equivalent and any foundational course.

title: Health Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course will examine psychological and physical health and the relationship between them. Research from mindfulness theory, mind/body studies, and positive psychology will be discussed along with research on stress, medical decision-making, behavioral medicine and social psychological theories that are pertinent to health. SLS-20 or equivalent and any foundational course.

title: Health:  A Positive Psychology Perspective
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Why does it seem that some people are so resilient and content?  This course looks at psychological and physical health from the perspective of Positive Psychology. title: Psychology of Morality
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This class will survey the recent history and evolution of research in moral psychology, emphasizing the function of moral thought in the regulation of intra-psychic processes and the shaping of social judgment and interaction. Students will be expected to engage in interactive discussion as well as participate in experimental research. Science of Living Systems 20 or its predecessors and Psychology 13 or Psychology 15.

title: Psychology of Peak Performance in Athletics and its Consequences
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course seeks to understand the physical and psychological behaviors as well as the mental training components necessary to achieve peak sport performance. Students will also gain an understanding of the physical, affective, and cognitive consequences of competitive sport participation. This includes the psychological factors that influence sport performance (e.g., self-confidence, arousal), methods for enhancing sport performance (e.g., goal-setting, imagery), and the negative consequences of becoming an elite athlete (e.g., burnout, concussions). Science of Living Systems 20 and at least one course from PSY 13, PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS15.

title: Psychology of Peak Performance in Athletics and its Consequences
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course seeks to understand the physical and psychological behaviors as well as the mental training components necessary to achieve peak sport performance. Students will also gain an understanding of the physical, affective, and cognitive consequences of competitive sport participation. This includes the psychological factors that influence sport performance (e.g., self-confidence, arousal), methods for enhancing sport performance (e.g., goal-setting, imagery), and the negative consequences of becoming an elite athlete (e.g., burnout, concussions). Science of Living Systems 20 and at least one course from PSY 13, PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS15.

title: Impediments to Excelling: Social Threat, Ostracism, Anxiety, and Choking
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The purpose of the course is to understand the effects of social threat, ostracism, anxiety, and choking on performance, and how to overcome them. This includes understanding the different types of impediments to excelling, how these impediments influence performance, and ultimately, how understanding these impediments lead to interventions to overcome them. Past and present empirical research and theory will be examined. Science of Living Systems 20 and at least one course from PSY 13, PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS15.

title: Impediments to Excelling: Social Threat, Ostracism, Anxiety, and Choking
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The purpose of the course is to understand the effects of social threat, ostracism, anxiety, and choking on performance, and how to overcome them. This includes understanding the different types of impediments to excelling, how these impediments influence performance, and ultimately, how understanding these impediments lead to interventions to overcome them. Past and present empirical research and theory will be examined. Science of Living Systems 20 and at least one course from PSY 13, PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS15.

title: Psychology of Women
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How does being a woman affect our behavior, our evaluations of ourselves, and our interactions with others? This course examines psychological science on women and girls in western industrialized societies, addressing such topics as gender stereotypes, girlhood, women and work, relationships, pregnancy and motherhood, mental health, violence against women, and women in later adulthood. We will consider these topics through an understanding of gender as a social construction, being mindful of the intersections of gender, sexuality, class, and race. Although focused on women’s lives and experiences, this course is highly relevant to people of all genders.

Although focused on women’s lives and experiences, this course is highly relevant to people of all genders.

title: Psychology of Women
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How does being a woman or man affect our behavior, our evaluations of ourselves, and our interactions with others? This course examines psychological science on women and girls in western industrialized societies, addressing such topics as gender stereotypes, girlhood, women and work, relationships, pregnancy and motherhood, mental health, violence against women, and women in later adulthood. We will consider these topics through an understanding of gender as a social construction, being mindful of the intersections of gender, sexuality, class, and race. Although focused on women's lives and experiences, this course is also highly relevant to men. Science of Living Systems 20 and at least one course from PSY 13, PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS15

title: Human Intelligence and IQ
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The study and measurement of human intelligence is one of the most controversial subjects in psychology. Some of the main issues that will be covered in this course include the modern development of IQ tests, the heritability of intelligence, theories of intelligence, environmental effects on IQ, relationship of cognitive psychology to measuring IQ, and intelligence in the social context.

title: Human Intelligence and IQ
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The study and measurement of human intelligence is one of the most controversial subjects in psychology. Some of the main issues that will be covered in this course include the modern development of IQ tests, the heritability of intelligence, theories of intelligence, environmental effects on IQ, relationship of cognitive psychology to measuring IQ, and intelligence in the social context.

title: Game Theory and Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Game theory is a mathematical model typically used to analyze behavior of firms and other "rational agents," but here we will apply this tool to psychological questions such as why people speak indirectly and where our moral intuitions or sense of beauty come from. Models of learning and evolution will be used to justify the applicability of game theory. Problem sets will involve rudimentary math and programming, but can be done in groups and no prerequisite knowledge is required. Students will also be required to read and discuss research papers and conduct original research as a final project. Science of Living Systems 20 or the equivalent.

title: Psychology of Willpower
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: It’s two in the morning. Will you finally write that paper, or will you give up and go to sleep? You are not the only person who faces dilemmas like these -- self-control is challenging, and everyone struggles with it.  How do we find the willpower to do the things we will be happy about tomorrow – and stay away from things we regret?  This course brings together insights from psychology, psychiatry, neuroscience, and behavioral economics to identify how we can break old habits and forge new ones, resist temptation, and pursue goals. Students will learn about the science of self-control and will put empirically-supported strategies to the test in their own lives.

title: Psychology of Music
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Why do we turn to Adele when sad? Play classical music to help focus? Go sing karaoke on a night out with friends? Music has the ability to influence our emotions, spark creativity, and influence relationships with people around us. But what makes music so universal? In this course, we will examine how listening to music, playing an instrument, and composing new music affect and are affected by a person’s psychology. We will cover topics such as what makes music sounds happy vs. sad, how music can be used for therapy, and whether animals can actually dance along to music, through the lens of psychological science.

title: The Mind's Eye: Psychology of Imagination
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Day dreaming. Having a song stuck in your head. Trying to picture a diagram from the textbook during a test. All of these activities require some sort of imagination, or simulating ideas, images or concepts that do not physically exist around you. We use imagination to guide us when making decisions ("What will happen if I choose this?"), when playing with friends ("Pretend the floor is lava!"), and when remembering past events ("I can almost picture it."). This course will examine the psychology of imagination to uncover how and why we imagine. By exploring the role of imagination in children's play as well as in hallucinations common to schizophrenia, we will trace the functions of fantasizing across development and individuals. Though the course will focus largely on visual and verbal imagery, we will spend a little time on auditory and other sensory imaginations as well.

title: How Students Learn: Psychological Science in the Classroom
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: As students, we can become accustomed to sitting through hours of lectures, transcribing those lectures, and cramming for exams. But is this the best educational method for promoting student learning?  And are the same strategies effective for everyone?  This course explores the intersections of psychology and education to reveal the science underlying the best practices of learning and teaching.  Topics include the influence of attention, cognitive development, emotion regulation, stereotype threat, growth mindset, and motivation on learning.  Through in-class demonstrations and the development of evidence-based lessons, we will wrestle with how to apply psychological principles to enhance the practice of teaching and learning. This course includes an experiential component in which you will learn study strategies and practical tips to enhance your own learning and performance in the classroom.

title: Laboratory Methods in Experimental Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces experimental methods used in psychology. Students conduct experiments and write journal-style laboratory reports. Experiments cover topics in sensation, perception, motivation, psychopharmacology, and psychophysiology. Lectures and readings provide the intellectual context for experiments.

title: Laboratory Methods in Experimental Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces experimental methods used in psychology. Students conduct experiments and write journal-style laboratory reports. Experiments cover topics in sensation, perception, motivation, psychopharmacology, and psychophysiology. Lectures and readings provide the intellectual context for experiments.

title: Laboratory Methods in Experimental Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces experimental methods used in psychology. Students carry out a variety of experiments on topics including sensation, perception, learning, motivation, and psychopharmacology. Hands-on experience and creative input to research design are emphasized. Students write journal-style laboratory reports, providing the opportunity to develop skills in scientific writing. Final project allows students to initiate independent study of a topic that may lead to thesis research.

title: Laboratory Methods in Experimental Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces experimental methods used in psychology. Students carry out a variety of experiments on topics including sensation, perception, learning, motivation, and psychopharmacology. Hands-on experience and creative input to research design are emphasized. Students write journal-style laboratory reports, providing the opportunity to develop skills in scientific writing. Final project allows students to initiate independent study of a topic that may lead to thesis research.

title: Human Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discussion of the organization of development from birth to adolescence and of the biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors that influence the developmental process. Readings, discussions, and assignments focus on current research and theory in developmental psychology. Weekly meetings include one large group lecture and one small group lecture/discussion with the professor. Additional section meetings to be arranged.

title: Human Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discussion of the organization of development from birth to adolescence and of the biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors that influence the developmental process. Readings, discussions, and assignments focus on current research and theory in developmental psychology.

title: Human Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discussion of the organization of development from birth to adolescence and of the biological, psychological, and sociocultural factors that influence the developmental process. Readings, discussions, and assignments focus on current research and theory in developmental psychology. Weekly meetings include one large group lecture and one small group lecture/discussion with the professor; additional section meetings to be arranged.

title: Introduction to Personality Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Designed to acquaint students with research and theory in personality psychology. Topics include the development, structure, and assessment of personality from historical and current perspectives. Biological and sociocultural influences are also considered.

title: Introduction to Personality Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Designed to acquaint students with research and theory in personality psychology. Topics include the development, structure, and assessment of personality from historical and current perspectives. Biological and sociocultural influences are also considered.

title: Introduction to Personality Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Designed to acquaint students with theories, research, and current issues in the field of personality.

title: Introduction to Personality Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Historical and philosophical foundations of personality theory; current theory and research; role of intelligence, temperament, and social structure; recent contributions from animal learning theory.

title: Introduction to Social Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes human behavior and thought as a function of the interactions among individual psychological processes, other people and groups of people, and social definitions and norms. Topics include social influence, social cognition, interpersonal attraction, individual-group relationships, and the methodology and ethics of social psychological research.

title: Introduction to Social Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Analyzes human behavior and thought as a function of the interactions among individual psychological processes, other people and groups of people, and social definitions and norms. Topics include social influence, social cognition, interpersonal attraction, individual-group relationships, and the methodology and ethics of social psychological research.

title: MATLAB: Introduction to Programming for Behavioral Research
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course will introduce students to the basics of the MATLAB user interface and programming language, for the purpose of using MATLAB to conduct behavioral research. In the first half of the course, you will learn about MATLAB syntax, general programming concepts such as functions, loops, and conditional statements, and how to analyze and visualize data in MATLAB. In the second half of the course, you will learn to program psychology experiments with the Psychophysics toolbox (a set of MATLAB functions), including displaying stimuli (visual and auditory), and collecting responses from participants. All students are required to bring a laptop computer to class. Open to graduate and undergraduate students with permission of instructor.

title: Topics in General Psychology: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers selected topics in learning, perception, motivation and emotion, personality, and social behavior. Term projects. Group work. Oral reports. Provides a review of the discipline for senior concentrators not engaged in an honors project.

title: Rediscovering the Mind: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Consciousness conceived as a topic of scientific study. Physiological, perceptual, psychological, and philosophical aspects are considered. Preference given to junior and senior psychology concentrators.

title: The Application of fMRI in Cognitive Neuroscience Research
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) is one of the most widely used methods in cognitive neuroscience research. In this course, students will learn the basics of fMRI research and gain hands-on experience in conducting fMRI experiments. In the first part of the course, students will have an overview of the fMRI methods, including how fMRI works, basic designs of fMRI experiments, fMRI data collection, analysis and interpretation, and current applications of fMRI in cognitive neuroscience research. In the second part of the course, students will design and conduct fMRI experiments and analyze fMRI data.

title: Sex, Evolution, and Human Behavior
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Evolutionary Psychology can be conceptualized as the study of: 1) the conditions in ancestral populations that rendered certain behaviors adaptive and others non-adaptive, 2) the mechanisms natural selection shaped to produce the adaptive behaviors, and 3) the ways in which these evolved mechanisms function now. Evolutionary Psychology provides a new and often insightful perspective to all areas of psychology, with particular success so far in cognitive psychology, social psychology, personality psychology, developmental psychology, and the psychology of emotions, to name a few areas. This course will cover how Evolutionary Psychology sheds light on the phenomena traditionally studied in these areas. SLS 20 and at least one course from Psy 13, Psy 14, Psy 15, Psy 18, or SLS 15.

title: Sex, Evolution, and Human Behavior
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Evolutionary Psychology can be conceptualized as the study of: 1) the conditions in ancestral populations that rendered certain behaviors adaptive and others non-adaptive, 2) the mechanisms natural selection shaped to produce the adaptive behaviors, and 3) the ways in which these evolved mechanisms function now. This course will cover how Evolutionary Psychology sheds light on the phenomena traditionally studied in these areas. Science of Living Systems 20 or its predecessors, and any foundational course.

title: Tics, Appetites, and Habits
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discussion of factors that control eating, addiction, procrastination, and tics. Readings drawn primarily from experimental and clinical research. Emphasis on relationship between clinical disorders and general behavioral and biological mechanisms.

title: Tics, Appetites, and Habits
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discussion of factors that control bad habits, eating, addiction, and tics. Readings drawn primarily from experimental and clinical research. Emphasis on relationship between clinical disorders and general behavioral and biological mechanisms.

title: Sex, Evolution, and Human Behavior
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Evolutionary Psychology can be conceptualized as the study of: 1) the conditions in ancestral populations that rendered certain behaviors adaptive and others non-adaptive, 2) the mechanisms natural selection shaped to produce the adaptive behaviors, and 3) the ways in which these evolved mechanisms function now. title: Psychology of Sexual Orientation
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines the science of sexual orientation from a biopsychosocial perspective. We will emphasize empirical research on a range of topics, including variations in sexual identity (particularly homosexuality, bisexuality, and asexuality), the concepts of sexual fluidity and erotic plasticity, measurement and prevalence of sexual minorities, origin theories, prejudice and discrimination (including homophobia and heterosexism), minority stress and health disparities, social change and collective action, cultural variations in attitudes toward sexual minorities, same-sex relationships and parenting, as well as lifespan issues (e.g., sexual identity development, aging).

title: The Face as Visual Communication
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Few ^'^'objects'' in our environment have greater significance than the human face. Despite recent interest, systematic scientific knowledge about how we process and react to faces remains sparse. This seminar course reviews studies on the human face as the visual carrier of personal/group identity as well as cognitive and emotional states. Active participation by students is required. Course will consist of readings, discussion, and numerous laboratory projects/exercises conducted in small groups. Graduate students are welcome to enroll. Psychology 13 or Science B-44 or permission of instructor.

title: Psychology of Sexual Orientation
subject: PSY

title: In Search of the Perfect School
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Is there a formula for the “perfect” school? Guided by this overarching question, you will critically analyze and creatively integrate theory, research, and policy with a particular focus on the application of educational psychology in secondary school. This focus serves as a window into many of the most topical and interesting issues facing our students and schools.

title: In Search of the Perfect School
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Is there a formula for the “perfect” school? Guided by this overarching question, you will critically analyze and creatively integrate theory, research, and policy with a particular focus on the application of educational psychology in secondary school. This focus serves as a window into many of the most topical and interesting issues facing our students and schools.

title: Social Cognitive Neuroscience: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores a handful of topics from the perspectives of social psychology, cognitive psychology, and neuropsychology. For any given phenomenon (e.g., the cognitive control of emotion), social psychology emphasizes phenomenology (what do people do when they want to manage their moods?), cognitive psychology emphasizes information-processing models (how might cognitive and emotional systems be designed to control each other?), and neuropsychology emphasizes biological underpinnings (where in the brain does emotional control occur?). The seminar offers a multi-level analysis of complex phenomena and attempts to integrate otherwise disparate approaches to similar problems. Psychology 1 plus one or more psychology distribution courses.

title: Explaining Academic Achievement
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Is there a formula for academic success? Would it be the same for every student? Guided by these overarching questions, we will survey some of the most interesting and important factors that facilitate achievement during different stages of formal schooling. You will be introduced to the theoretical roots, empirical evidence, and practical implications of these factors as we integrate them throughout the semester to create an equation that attempts to explain academic achievement.

title: Explaining Academic Achievement
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Is there a formula for academic success? Would it be the same for every student? Guided by these overarching questions, we will survey some of the most interesting and important factors that facilitate achievement during different stages of formal schooling. You will be introduced to the theoretical roots, empirical evidence, and practical implications of these factors as we integrate them throughout the semester to create an equation that attempts to explain academic achievement.

title: Maps of Meaning: Narrative and the Cortical Regulation of Emotion
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Atempts to integrate modern findings regarding the conceptual and real nervous systems _ with particular emphasis on the regulation of emotion _ with theories derived from the comparative study of religion and narrative. The course will be predicated upon the notion that the higher-order cognitive/verbal faculties characteristic of human beings regular affect and behavior through use of narrative; and that culture itself (which allows groups of human beings to mutually and predictably inter-regulate their emotions and actions) has a narrative structure.

title: Maps of Meaning: Narrative and the Cortical Regulation of Emotion
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Atempts to integrate modern findings regarding the conceptual and real nervous systems _ with particular emphasis on the regulation of emotion _ with theories derived from the comparative study of religion and narrative. The course will be predicated upon the notion that the higher-order cognitive/verbal faculties characteristic of human beings regular affect and behavior through use of narrative; and that culture itself (which allows groups of human beings to mutually and predictably inter-regulate their emotions and actions) has a narrative structure.

title: Music and the Mind
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Music is universal, pervasive in our everyday lives, and compelling. How does music make our emotions soar, spark our creativity, and influence our relationships and interactions with others? This course will examine how the brain creates and experiences music, how music in turn shapes our brains and tunes our ability to engage with our external environment, and what music reveals about the ability of the human brain to co-opt evolutionarily ancient mechanisms for seemingly "unique" human faculties. We will cover the relationship between music and emotions, movement, creativity, and sociality.

How does music make our emotions soar, spark our creativity, and influence our relationships and interactions with others? This course will examine how the brain creates and experiences music, how music in turn shapes our brains and tunes our ability to engage with our external environment, and what music reveals about the ability of the human brain to co-opt evolutionarily ancient mechanisms for seemingly "unique" human faculties. We will cover the relationship between music and emotions, movement, creativity, and sociality.

title: Psychology of Consumer Behavior
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Psychological theory and research findings have wide and varied applications to almost every other field; the world of business marketing is no exception. Understanding the thoughts, attitudes, and behaviors of consumers is imperative for the success of businesses, governments, and, in fact, anyone else looking to influence others. The purpose of this course is to provide working knowledge of psychological concepts related to consumer behavior including but not limited to memory, attitudes, preferences, judgments, and decision making. In addition, the course aims to use case studies and research projects to develop the ability to apply and evaluate influential strategies that make use of these psychological concepts.

title: Origins of Evil
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course begins with historical, theological, and philosophical debates concerning the nature of evil, ranging from romantic views that consider human nature good and perceive the environment as corrosive, to determinist views that perceive biology as the problem. We then engage recent evidence from genetics, cognitive neuroscience, anthropology, and evolutionary psychology to illuminate these theories and alight upon new understanding of our capacity for evil. Science of Living Systems 20 or its predecessors and any Tier 2 course, or permission of instructor..

title: Human Motivation
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Factors that arouse, sustain, and direct behavior examined from the perspectives of psychoanalysis, behaviorism, neuropsychology, philosophy, and personality theory with particular emphasis on achievement and competence motivation. Other topics include sex differences in human social motives, self-deception, and human motivation characterized in literature and the media.

title: Human Motivation
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines factors that arouse, energize, and sustain behavior from psychobiological, personological, and cognitive perspectives. Covers topics such as arousal and performance, sleeping and wakefulness, thirst, hunger and eating, sexual arousal, drug use and addiction, and the motivation for achievement and power. Also explores the importance of emotion in motivating these various behaviors.

title: Human Motivation
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines factors that arouse, energize, and sustain behavior from psychobiological, personological, and cognitive perspectives. Covers topics such as arousal and performance, sleeping and wakefulness, thirst, hunger and eating, sexual arousal, drug use and addiction, and the motivation for achievement and power. Also explores the importance of emotion in motivating these various behaviors.

title: Human Motivation
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Factors that arouse, sustain, and direct behavior examined from the perspectives of psychoanalysis, behaviorism, neuropsychology, philosophy, and personality theory with particular emphasis on achievement and competence motivation. Other topics include sex differences in human social motives, self-deception, and human motivation characterized in literature and the media.

title: Behavior, Learning, and Choice
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on behavioral mechanisms that mediate behavioral output, learning, and choice. Topics include fixed-action patterns, associative learning, operant conditioning, concept formation, behavioral and economic theories of choice. Surveys algebraic models of learning and choice, and an empirical literature drawn largely but not exclusively from experiments on animals. Representative studies on humans are also described.

title: Behavior, Learning, and Choice
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Topics include instinct, learning, choice, and behavioral economics. Emphasis on experimental studies, with some discussion of applications to clinical and related issues (e.g., phobias, addiction, and impulsivity).

title: Behavior, Learning, and Choice
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Topics include instinct, learning, choice, and behavioral economics. Emphasis on experimental studies, with some discussion of applications to clinical and related issues (e.g., phobias, addiction, and impulsivity).

title: Psychobiology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to brain processes underlying behavior, including the physiological mechanisms involved in sensation and perception, control of movement, learning and memory, language, emotion and motivation, and sleep. Surveys research on mental illness and neurological disease, as well as computer models of brain function. Introductory biology strongly recommended.

title: Psychobiology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to brain processes underlying behavior, including the physiological mechanisms involved in sensation and perception, control of movement, learning and memory, language, emotion and motivation, and sleep. Surveys research on mental illness and neurological disease, as well as computer models of brain function. Introductory biology strongly recommended.

title: Psychobiology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An overview of behavioral neuroscience, focusing on the biological basis of sensation, perception, movement, learning and memory, and psychopathology. These topics are discussed in the context of our current knowledge of neuroanatomy, physiology, and pharmacology. Introductory biology strongly recommended.

title: Psychology of Economic Decision Making
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of psychological mechanisms in decision-making contexts such as rational choice, intertemporal choice, cooperation, fairness, punishment, and signaling. Focuses on the effects of learning, memory, attention, self-control, framing, and theory of mind on choice behavior in both humans and nonhuman animals.

title: Psychology of Economic Decision Making
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of psychological mechanisms in decision-making contexts such as rational choice, intertemporal choice, cooperation, fairness, punishment, and signaling. Focuses on the effects of learning, memory, attention, self-control, framing, and theory of mind on choice behavior in both humans and nonhuman animals.

title: Psychology of Economic Decision Making
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the role of psychological mechanisms in decision-making contexts such as rational choice, intertemporal choice, cooperation, fairness, punishment, and signaling. Focuses on the effects of learning, memory, attention, self-control, framing, and theory of mind on choice behavior in both humans and nonhuman animals.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines perception, attention, memory, language use, knowledge representation, reasoning, and problem solving. Emphasis on computational theories of human cognition, focusing on the empirical support for these theories as well as the influence of research from other disciplines (e.g., artifical intelligence, neuroscience, linguistics, animal behavior) on their formulation.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines perception, attention, memory, language use, knowledge representation, reasoning, and problem solving. Emphasis on computational theories of human cognition, focusing on the empirical support for these theories as well as the influence of research from other disciplines (e.g., artificial intelligence, neuroscience, linguistics, animal behavior) on their formulation.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines perception, attention, memory, language use, knowledge representation, reasoning, and problem solving. Emphasis on computational theories of human cognition, focusing on the empirical support for these theories as well as the influence of research from other disciplines (e.g., artifical intelligence, neuroscience, linguistics, animal behavior) on their formulation.

title: Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines perception, attention, memory, language use, and knowledge representation from the viewpoint of the computational theory of mind. Emphasis on how empirical and theoretical results have jointly influenced our understanding of mental processes.

title: Introduction to Learning
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The capacity to learn is one of the most distinctive features of animals, both human and infrahuman. Examines biological and psychological mechanisms that support learning. Content drawn from animal and human studies. Topics include fixed action patterns, classical and operant conditioning, motivation, choice, self-control, and concept formation. Also examines how theories of learning make contact with other areas of psychology, including social, abnormal, and cognitive.

title: Behavior, Learning, and Choice
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on behavioral mechanisms that mediate behavioral output, learning, and choice. Topics include fixed-action patterns, associative learning, operant conditioning, concept formation, behavioral and economic theories of choice. Surveys algebraic models of learning and choice, and an empirical literature drawn largely but not exclusively from experiments on animals. Representative studies on humans are also described.

title: Perceptual Processes
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Processes of constructing and representing the world from sensory signals, considered at biological, phenomenological, philosophical, and formal levels. Examines specific neural and computational mechanisms for the extraction of visual and auditory information and its integration into recognizable objects and events. Major focus on vision, natural and artificial. Stresses theory and the evaluation of explanatory strategies such as those associated with modern and classical Gestalt psychology, psychophysics, neurophysiology, formal neural networks, and artificial intelligence.

title: Perception and Imagination
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Perception is required to have a mind like yours. How does perceiving work? How are streams of sensory input processed into rich and useful models of the world around you? This course will converge on the 5 senses from many informative angles, explaining how perception tracks and shapes reality, then gives rise to imagination.

title: Sensation and Perception
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Investigates the functioning of sensory systems and the active interpretation of sensory information that leads to awareness of the physical world. Although vision is the major focus, the other senses are also covered. Topics include the general structure and function of the sensory nervous system, transduction and neural coding, psychophysics, the traditional illusions and perceptual constancies, and speech perception. Demonstrations and individual hand-on experience are part of the course.

title: Perception and Imagination
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Perception is required to have a mind like yours. How does perceiving work? How are streams of sensory input processed into rich and useful models of the world around you? This course will converge on the 5 senses from many informative angles, explaining how perception tracks and shapes reality, then gives rise to imagination. Science of Living Systems 20 and at least one course from PSY 13, PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS 15.

title: Perception
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Everything we know about the world comes to us through our senses. How is energy in the environment transduced into our sensations? How do those sensations get interpreted into our perceptions of the world and of our relationship to the world? Do limits on perception impose limits on our mental life? Course surveys vision, hearing, taste, smell, touch, and vestibular senses. Greatest emphasis on vision. Discusses behavioral and biological data with more emphasis on behavior. Psychology 1; and either Psychology 13 or MCB 80.

title: Perception

title: Cognitive Evolution: Theory and Practice
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on theoretical and practical matters concerned with the evolution of the human mind. We take a multi-disciplinary approach that includes evolutionary theory, neurobiology, cognitive science, animal behavior, developmental biology, linguistics, economics, anthropology, and philosophy. We address such issues as the nature of non-linguistic representation; evolution of cooperation, language, and morality; how mathematical quantification, navigation, and communication evolved; and whether the mind has an optimal design. Includes experiments with human adults, children, monkeys, and birds.

title: Animal Cognition: Laboratory
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to issues, laboratory techniques, and field methodology in animal cognition. Students develop and pilot research projects. Empirical research is accompanied by a critical reading and discussion of papers on such topics as language evolution, concept acquisition, acoustic perception, and domain-specific knowledge. Science B-29 or Biology 22 or permission of instructor.

title: Evolutionary Ethics: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the biological foundations of our ethical behavior, integrating theoretical and empirical advances from evolutionary biology, cognitive science, neurobiology, economics, philosophy, and law. Discusses evolution of religion, legal issues, nonhuman morals, and human values. Graduate students welcome.

title: Cognitive Evolution
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on theoretical and practical matters concerned with the evolution of the human mind. We take a multi-disciplinary approach that includes evolutionary theory, neurobiology, cognitive science, animal behavior, developmental biology, linguistics, economics, anthropology, and philosophy. We address such issues as the nature of non-linguistic representation; evolution of cooperation, language, and morality; how mathematical quantification, navigation, and communication evolved; and whether the mind has an optimal design. Includes experiments with human adults, children, monkeys, and birds. Science of Living Systems 20 or its predecessors and any Tier 2 course.

title: Evolutionary Ethics: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the biological foundations of our ethical behavior, integrating theoretical and empirical advances from evolutionary biology, cognitive science, neurobiology, economics, philosophy, and law. Discusses evolution of religion, legal issues, nonhuman morals, and human values. Graduate students welcome.

title: Vision
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the visual system from early to higher levels. Explores the links to neurophysiology, computer vision, and neuropsychology. Covers topics such as object and face recognition, perception of depth, color, texture, and motion, visually guided movement, visual memory, and localization of function in vision. Project sessions on topics to be arranged. Builds on material from Science B-44 (not a prerequisite). At least one course in perception, computer vision, or visual neuroscience.

title: Vision
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the visual system from early to higher levels. Explores the links to neurophysiology, computer vision, and neuropsychology. Covers topics such as object and face recognition, perception of depth, color, texture, and motion, visually guided movement, visual memory, and localization of function in vision. Project sessions on topics to be arranged. Builds on material from Science B-44 (not a prerequisite). At least one course in perception, computer vision, or visual neuroscience.

title: Cognitive Science
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on how information is represented and stored in the human mind with emphasis on computer models of mental functioning. Topics center on the mental processing underlying language use, perception, and reasoning, and include contributions from artificial intelligence, neuropsychology, and developmental approaches to cognition.

title: Cognitive Science
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on how information is represented and stored in the human mind with emphasis on computer models of mental functioning. Topics center on the mental processing underlying language use, perception, and reasoning, and include contributions from artificial intelligence, neuropsychology, and developmental approaches to cognition.

title: Connectionist Models: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines a variety of connectionist processing systems, as well as connectionist models of psychological processes. Compares connectionism with other sorts of computational models. Each student will perform and present a research project involving the development or application of a connectionist system. At least one course in cognitive psychology or artificial intelligence.

title: Connectionist Models
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines a variety of connectionist processing systems, as well as several connectionist models of psychological processes. Compares connectionism with other sorts of computational models. Each student will perform and present a research project involving the development or application of a connectionist system. Conducted as a seminar. At least one course in cognitive psychology or artificial intelligence.

title: Connectionist Models: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines a variety of connectionist processing systems, as well as connectionist models of psychological processes. Compares connectionism with other sorts of computational models. Each student will perform and present a research project involving the development or application of a connectionist system. At least one course in cognitive psychology or artificial intelligence.

title: Minds, Brains, and Computers
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: All mental activity, such as solving problems, recognizing objects, and doing mathematics, arises from activity of the brain. Thus, it is not surprising that brain damage disrupts mental activity. However, the specific ways in which brain damage disrupts mental activity often are surprising. This course explores the implications of specific types of behavioral dysfunction following brain damage for theories of human information processing.

title: Behavioral Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to brain processes underlying behavior, including the physiological mechanisms involved in sensation and perception, control of movement, learning and memory, language, emotion and motivation, and sleep. Surveys research on mental illness and neurological disease, as well as computer models of brain function. Introductory biology strongly recommended.

title: The Age of Reason
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discusses research literature dealing with developmental changes in children near the age of schooling. A number of Western and non-Western societies conceive of this period as an age of reason. So, too, do some prominent theorists of human development. But the research now raises questions and holds out other possibilities, and these have interesting theoretical and practical implications. Two or more courses in psychology.

title: Your Brain on Drugs: Psychopharmacology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to how drugs affect mood, sensation, consciousness, and other psychological and behavioral functions in both healthy and disease states. Introduces concepts in neuroscience and pharmacology to understand how drugs are used to treat drug abuse, psychiatric disorders and why individuals use recreational drugs. Covers all CNS drugs, including antidepressants, antipsychotics, alcohol, and both licit and illicit drugs of abuse. Debates controversial topics such as research with psychiatric populations, diagnosing ADHD, teenage suicide, marijuana legalization, and needle exchange programs.

Biological Sciences 25 or equivalent.

title: Modern Neuroanatomy
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How does the global architecture and local organization of brain systems support behavioral and cognitive functions? In this class, classical and newer neuroanatomical discoveries will be discussed that cover what defines brain areas; how areas are organized into parallel, distributed circuits; how distinct areas and systems are organized; and how anatomical form relates to function. Anatomy in the human brain and from model systems (worm, mouse, barn owl, and monkey) will be used to illustrate principles. Newer techniques and analytical approaches will be discussed including micro-scale and macro-scale connectomics. The goal of this class is to survey examples of how emerging understanding of neuroanatomy provides insight into function. Each class will consist of lecture and discussion.

title: Human Behavior and the Developing Brain
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an overview of knowledge about brain and behavior development in human beings across the life cycle. The focus will be normal human development, although there will be discussion of pathology and of findings with animals where relevant. The two instructors bring complementary backgrounds in psychology, human neurology, and education. Topics will include normal neurological development in human beings, cognitive and emotional development, nonlinear dynamics of development, and especially relations between development of brain and behavior. Offered jointly with the School of Education as H-134.

title: Functional Neuroimaging: Basic Methods and Results
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Functional mapping of the human brain is an area of rapid growth, both scientifically and technologically. This class deals with the methods and experimental results of recent developments in functional neuroimaging: making pictures of the working human brain. The underlying physics and physiology for various methods for monitoring human brain function will be presented. Data analysis, including the creation of ^'^'maps'' of the localization of brain function, will be examined in detail. Emphasis will be on the techniques of Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI), but all modalities will be discussed. Students will be required to design experiments, in consultation with the instructor.

title: Functional Neuroimaging: Basic Methods and Results
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Functional mapping of the human brain is an area of rapid growth, both scientifically and technologically. This class deals with the methods and experimental results of recent developments in functional neuroimaging: making pictures of the working human brain. Presents underlying physics and physiology for various methods of monitoring human brain function and creating ^'^'maps'' of the localization of brain function. Presents and discusses latest results in a collection of specific areas. Course both explicates methods and examines the results of these methods in detail.

title: Hormones and Behavior
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines how hormones act in the nervous system and influence specific behaviors, and vice versa. Covers literature concerning sexual differentiation, reproduction, parental behaviors, aggression, mood, stress, eating and drinking, learning and memory, and psychopathology. Psychology 1 and BS 25 or 80, or consent of instructor.

title: Hormones and Behavior
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines how hormones act in the nervous system and influence specific behaviors, and vice versa. Covers literature concerning sexual differentiation, reproduction, parental behaviors, aggression, mood, stress, eating and drinking, learning and memory, and psychopathology. Psychology 1 and BS 25 or 80, or consent of instructor.

title: Hormones and Behavior
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines how hormones act in the nervous system and influence specific behaviors, and vice versa. Covers literature concerning sexual differentiation, reproduction, parental behaviors, aggression, mood, stress, eating and drinking, learning and memory, and psychopathology. Psychology 1 and BS 25 or 80, or consent of instructor.

title: Stimulant Drugs: From Neurobiology to Ethics
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The use of stimulants in the US is both common and controversial. Stimulants are effective for both the treatment of disabling disorders and the enhancement of cognitive function in people who are well. Ethical and policy issues include the undermining of personal responsibility, fairness, coercion, and effects on personal identity. The course will examine these issues as well as epidemiology, clinical trials data, and, to a substantial degree, the neural basis of stimulant action. BS 80 recommended but not required. Optional additional sections on basic concepts of neuroscience may be scheduled for those who have not had BS80 or the equivalent.

title: Brain, Drugs, and Society: From Neurobiology to Ethics
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Progress in psychopharmacology has produced drugs that not only treat illnesses, but also can influence behavior in people who are not ill. Ethical and policy issues have been raised about whether such uses might undermine personal responsibility, have unintended personal consequences, or exacerbate societal disparities. This course will give equal weight to how certain drugs (e.g., stimulants, antidepressants, memory altering drugs, addictive drugs) act in the brain and to ethical issues raised by their use. MCB 80 or equivalent.

title: Human Psychophysiology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Psychophysiological study concerns the relationship between psychology and physiology. Goals are to understand psychological events through interpretation of physiological signals recorded noninvasively from humans. Readings and discussion are interdisciplinary, relating psychological phenomena with principles of physiology and biomedical recording. Topics include lie detection, cardiovascular responsivity, patterns of brain wave activity. Laboratory sections provide hands-on experience with recording procedures. Relevance of psychophysiological data for cognitive, clinical, and social psychology discussed.

title: Human Psychophysiology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Psychophysiological study concerns the relationship between psychology and physiology. Goals are to understand psychological events through interpretation of physiological signals recorded noninvasively from humans. Readings and discussion are interdisciplinary, relating psychological phenomena with principles of physiology and electricity. Topics include lie detection, cardiovascular responsivity, patterns of brain wave activity. Laboratory sections provide hands-on experience with recording procedures. Relevance of psychophysiological data for cognitive, clinical, and social psychology discussed.

title: Child Psychopathology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the major forms of childhood disturbances, emphasizing issues, theory, and research. Focus on understanding psychopathology within a developmental framework. Discusses disorders such as autism, attention deficit, and anorexia, and the issue of the continuity of child psychopathology and adult functioning. Competence in the basic literature of child development.

title: Abnormal Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the study of psychopathology. Focus on theoretical models of abnormal behavior, diagnostic classification, and the behavioral and biological features of the major syndromes of psychopathology. An introductory course in psychology.

title: Abnormal Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the study of psychopathology. Lectures focus on theoretical models of abnormal behavior, diagnostic classification, and the behavioral and biopsychological features of the major syndromes of psychopathology. An introductory course in psychology.

title: Abnormal Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the study of psychopathology. Focus on theoretical models of abnormal behavior, diagnostic classification, and the behavioral and biological features of the major syndromes of psychopathology. An introductory course in psychology.

title: Abnormal Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Introduction to the study of psychopathology. Focus on theoretical models of abnormal behavior, diagnostic classification, and the behavioral and biological features of the major syndromes of psychopathology. An introductory course in psychology.

title: Behavioral Medicine
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An overview of current theory and research linking psychosocial factors to health and disease. Central topics include systems theory and psychobiological models of specific disorders, stress and illness, personality, emotion, coping and defense, pain, bereavement, social support systems, and treatment intervention.

title: Behavioral Medicine (Health Psychology)
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An overview of current theory and research linking psychosocial factors to health and disease. Central topics include systems theory and psychobiological models of specific disorders, stress and illness, personality, emotion, coping and defense, pain, bereavement, social support systems, and treatment intervention.

title: Neural Networks
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of neural network theory and computational neuroscience, with emphasis on realistic models of hippocampal memory and processing. Includes survey of connectionist and computational neuroscience models of hippocampal and cortical processing. Associative memory function, place cells, oscillatory processes and self-organization are some of the topics that will be covered. Comparisons between abstract connectionist models, detailed biophysical models and experimental data will be a major discussion focus in this seminar.

title: Neural Networks
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of neural network theory and computational neuroscience, with emphasis on realistic models of hippocampal memory and processing. Includes survey of connectionist and computational neuroscience models of hippocampal and cortical processing. Associative memory function, place cells, oscillatory processes and self-organization are some of the topics that will be covered. Comparisons between abstract connectionist models, detailed biophysical models and experimental data will be a major discussion focus in this seminar.

title: Neural Networks
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of neural network theory, with emphasis on cortical self-organization and associative memory function. Includes survey of realistic models of olfactory cortex, hippocampus, and visual cortex, compartmental biophysical simulations, and more abstract, connectionist models of cognitive function.

title: Circuits and Symptoms
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This class will explore the biology of psychological illness. We will ignore artificial diagnostic labels, examining instead the core symptom domains that have plagued humans since the beginning of recorded history. A strong emphasis will be placed on biological mechanisms. In particular, the class will focus on mapping dysfunction in large-scale brain circuits to cognitive, affective, social, and motivational symptom domains, and on understanding how genes and environments act and interact to predispose these symptoms by shaping brain function and development. Preference given to graduate students and to Juniors and Seniors. SLS-20 and PSY 18 or PSY 14 or MCB 80.

title: Neural Networks
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of neural network theory and computational neuroscience, with emphasis on cortical self-regulation and associative memory function. includes survey of realistic models of olfactory cortex, small neural networks, and more abstract, connectionist models of cognitive function.

title: Neural Networks
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of neural network theory, with emphasis on cortical self-organization and associative memory function. Includes survey of realistic models of olfactory cortex, hippocampus, and visual cortex, compartmental biophysical simulations, and more abstract, connectionist models of cognitive function.

title: Neural Networks
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of neural network theory and computational neuroscience, with emphasis on realistic models of hippocampal memory and processing. Includes survey of connectionist and computational neuroscience models of hippocampal and cortical processing. Associative memory function, place cells, oscillatory processes and self-organization are some of the topics that will be covered. Comparisons between abstract connectionist models, detailed biophysical models and experimental data will be a major discussion focus in this seminar.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Consideration of experimental studies aimed at defining the neural systems involved in learning and remembering different types of information. The primary focus will be research attempting to to assign specific mnemonic functions to specific brain areas, and theories attempting to integrate what is known about the biological organization of the brain with the psychological phenomena of learning and memory.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the neural systems involved in learning and remembering. Focuses on research assigning specific mnemonic functions to specific brain areas, and integrates the biological organization of the brain with the psychological phenomena of learning and memory. Psychology 1 and BS 80.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Consideration of experimental studies aimed at defining the neural systems involved in learning and remembering different types of information. The primary focus will be research attempting to to assign specific mnemonic functions to specific brain areas, and theories attempting to integrate what is known about the biological organization of the brain with the psychological phenomena of learning and memory. Psychology 1 and Biological Sciences 25 or 80.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the neural systems involved in learning and remembering. Focuses on research assigning specific mnemonic functions to specific brain areas, and integrates the biological organization of the brain with the psychological phenomena of learning and memory. Graduate students encouraged to enroll. Psychology 1 and Biological Sciences 80.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Consideration of experimental studies aimed at defining the neural systems involved in learning and remembering different types of information. The primary focus will be research attempting to to assign specific mnemonic functions to specific brain areas, and theories attempting to integrate what is known about the biological organization of the brain with the psychological phenomena of learning and memory. Psychology 1 and Biological Sciences 25 or 80.

courseDescriptionLong: Consideration of experimental studies aimed at defining the neural systems involved in learning and remembering different types of information. The primary focus will be research attempting to to assign specific mnemonic functions to specific brain areas, and theories attempting to integrate what is known about the biological organization of the brain with the psychological phenomena of learning and memory.

title: Neurobiology of Learning and Memory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the neural systems involved in learning and remembering. Focuses on research assigning specific mnemonic functions to specific brain areas, and integrates the biological organization of the brain with the psychological phenomena of learning and memory. Psychology 1 and BS 80.

title: Laboratory in Behavioral Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Experimental studies of brain-behavior relationships provide an understanding of the organization of function within the central nervous system, as well as a window into potential substrates of brain disorders. Students develop and conduct research projects on the neural basis of behavior. Empirical research is accompanied by a critical reading and discussion of papers on such topics as the neurobiology of learning and memory, functional neuroanatomy,and the biological basis of neurodegenerative disease. Biological Science 25.

title: Laboratory in Behavioral Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Experimental studies of brain-behavior relationships provide an understanding of the organization of function within the central nervous system, as well as a window into potential substrates of brain disorders. Students develop and conduct research projects on the neural basis of behavior. Empirical research is accompanied by a critical reading and discussion of papers on such topics as the neurobiology of learning and memory, functional neuroanatomy,and the biological basis of neurodegenerative disease. Biological Science 25.

title: Neuropsychology of Aging and Dementia
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Provides an interdisciplinary synthesis of research on the cognitive changes that occur in normal aging and dementia. Considers both theoretical perspectives and methodological issues as they relate to declines in components of attention, learning, and memory. Both group differences and individual variability will be discussed, as we consider both behavioral and neurobiological evidence from human and nonhuman subjects. Psychology 1 and Biological Sciences 25 or 80.

title: The Neurobiological Basis of Consciousness
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: We trace the quest to identify the neural correlates of consciousness in a parallel lecture and seminar format. Lectures will be used to provide general background in neurobiology and psychology. Seminars will be employed for an in depth discussion of major contributions. Weekly lectures and two sections led by the instructor.

title: Language Evolution
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Why is human language unique among natural communication systems? We will discuss how to clarify this question and examine a range of evidence from biology and psychology that address it. Students will collaborate in selecting the seminar topics. Possible topics could include: origins of language, words and gestures, animal artificial language learning studies, natural nonhuman communication systems, language functions, adaptations and byproducts, hominid evolution and biomechanics, cultural evolution, historical linguistics, language development, computational modeling.

title: Eating Disorders
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An overview of major eating disorders: anorexia nervosa, bulimia, and obesity. Examines behavioral and psychobiological features, theoretical models, and rationale and efficacy of therapeutic intervention.

subject: PSY

title: Cognitive Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to the study of human cognition. Topics include perception, attention, memory, categorization, language, and consciousness. We will consider how human thought processes are organized, how they affect our everyday behavior, and the biological mechanisms that underlie them.

subject: PSY

subject: PSY

title: History of Developmental Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Lectures and discussions deal with efforts to study and influence the course of human development, beginning with some historic projects in the early 1800s (Itard's training of the "Wild Boy of Aveyron,'' James Mill's education of the young John Stuart Mill, Froebel's establishment of his Kindergarten). The course examines the child study movement at the turn of this century and its influence on the great growth of American schools at that time. Particular attention given to the formation of contemporary developmental psychology and the programs of Werner, Piaget, and Vygotsky.
