title: Reward and Self Control
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: What's stopping you from doing absolutely everything that your devious heart desires? The ability to flexibly control our behavior - particularly when it comes to rewarding things like food, sex, and drugs - has huge consequences for our long-term happiness and success. Though we are reasonably good at this as a species, dramatic individual differences in the capacity for self-control are readily apparent. In this class, we will examine the cognitive construct of self-control, its neurobiological underpinnings and sources of individual variation, and relationships to psychopathology. Science of Living Systems 20 and at least one course from PSY 13, PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS15.

title: Psychometric Theory and Method Using R
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong:
By its classical de nition, Psychometrics is concerned with the theory and techniques of psychological measurement. In this class we will cover a wide variety of modern psychometric methods; a big portion of them going beyond the classical psychometrics de nition boundaries.

We start the class with a variety of exploratory scaling methods (units 1-5) where the aim is to scale and visualize association patterns in complex, multivariate datasets. Such techniques include principal components analysis (PCA), correspondence analysis (CA), Gi models, multidimensional scaling (MDS), and biplots. There will also be a unit on networks where we cover basic (social) network analysis as well as more advanced techniques such as latent networks.

In the second part of the class (units 7-10) we focus on some classical psychometric approaches. The starting points is path models (which also include mediator/moderator models as special cases) which will then be extended to latent variable path models such as structural equation models (SEM). Subsequently, we will have two units on item response theory (IRT), which represents a large family of methods for scale construction and scale evaluation. We will cover unidimensional as well as multidimensional IRT models.

The third part of the class (units 11-12) focuses on the analysis of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data. We will learn how to work with big datasets in R, how to obtain a parametric map through a general linear model t, and how to deal with the huge multiple testing problem. Subsequently, the last unit deals with multivariate fMRI methods such as independent components analysis (ICA) and some aspects of multi-voxel pattern analysis (MVPA) such as representational similarity analysis (RSA).

All topics covered will be supported by corresponding computations and illustrations in R. Basic R knowledge is required for this class. Lab units will be scheduled if needed.

title: Psychometric Theory and Methods
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong:
By its classical definition, Psychometrics is concerned with the theory and techniques of psychological measurement. In this class we will cover a wide variety of modern psychometric methods; a big portion of them going beyond the classical psychometrics defi nition boundaries.

We start the class with a variety of exploratory scaling methods (units 1-5) where the aim is to scale and visualize association patterns in complex, multivariate datasets. Such techniques include principal components analysis (PCA), correspondence analysis (CA), Gi models, multidimensional scaling (MDS), and biplots. There will also be a unit on networks where we cover basic (social) network analysis as well as more advanced techniques such as latent networks.

In the second part of the class (units 7-10) we focus on some classical psychometric approaches. The starting points is path models (which also include mediator/moderator models as special cases) which will then be extended to latent variable path models such as structural equation models (SEM). Subsequently, we will have two units on item response theory (IRT), which represents a large family of methods for scale construction and scale evaluation. We will cover unidimensional as well as multidimensional IRT models.

title: Statistical Learning
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong:
The first series of lectures (units 1-4) covers advanced regression techniques. We extend the linear mixed-effects model in terms of non-linear effects which leads to generalized additive mixed-effects models (GAMM), with spline specifications at its core. At this point we will also introduce cross-validation as a tool for assessing predictive accuracy of a model while avoiding overfitting. This is followed by shrinkage/regularization techniques (Lasso) which are attractive for regression scenarios with many predictors. In the time series unit we introduce strategies for finding patterns in time trajectories and making corresponding predictions (ARIMA models, Holt-Winters smoothing).

In Unit 5 we model trajectories using concepts from functional data analysis (FDA) where each single individual is represented by a function (e.g. growth curve, EEG signal, etc.). Graphical models (Unit 6) allow us to model dependencies in complex multivariate datasets (e.g., studying relationships among clinical symptoms). In the subsequent units we move into Machine Learning territory. We start with unsupervised learning which is essentially clustering. Basic approaches such as hierarchical clustering techniques and k-means are explained. We proceed with borderline unsupervised/supervised approaches such as association rules and Kohonen networks. In Unit 9 we learn more advanced parametric clustering techniques (mixture distributions) which we will then integrate into a regression framework (mixture regression). Hidden Markov models will be introduced within this context as well.

The remaining three units are all about supervised learning where our aim is classification/prediction. Unit 10 presents tree-based approaches (decision/regression trees), model-based recursive partitioning (i.e., finding optimal predictor splits in e.g. a mixed-effects regression model), and ensemble tree learning (random forests).

In Unit 11 we briefly introduce discriminant analysis and extend it to support vector machines (SVM), often applied on fMRI data. Finally, we will cover neural networks and some modern “deep learning” flavors.

title: Issues in Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An overview of selected issues in development, concentrating on research data and theory in cognitive, affective, and social development during the first ten years. Emphasis given to infancy, stability, role of biology, and meaning of evidence. Open to senior concentrators in Psychology with a prior course in human development and with permission of instructor.

Emphasis given to infancy, stability, role of biology, and meaning of evidence. Open to senior concentrators in Psychology with a prior course in human development and with permission of instructor.

title: Research Methodology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How to conduct empirical research, primarily with human participants. Topics include formulating problems, design strategies, developing and validating concepts, designing and assessing measures and manipulations; issues in data collection, analysis, and interpretation; and publishing findings. Limited to doctoral students. Offered alternate years.

title: Research Methodology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Covers all major steps in conducting an empirical research project, with emphasis on studies that involve human participants. title: Emotion: Physiology, Development, and Culture: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines research and theory on the physiological bases of emotions, development of emotional processes, temperment, and cultural perspectives on emotions. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Research Methodology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How to conduct empirical research, primarily with human participants. title: Emotional Development: Biology, Relationships, Culture
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The relationship between emotion and cognition is complex. Based in social interaction, emotions are biological processes that organize human behavior by constraining thought and action, while relationships evoke and shape emotions. This course examines foundational work from the classics through modern emotion research about attribution, development, culture, and neuroscience. Questions include: How do relationships and learning shape emotions, and vice versa? What are pathways in the development of emotions? What can emotion sciences bring to practical questions about teaching and learning? Attention to risk and resilience, including poverty, stigmatization, disability, and trauma. Class format combines discussion, case analysis, and lecture.

Science of Living Systems 20 or its predecessors and any foundational course.

title: Emotional Development: Biology, Relationships, Culture
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the connections between biology, emotions, relationships, and culture. Reviews classic work such as Darwin and psychodynamics as well as modern emotion research about attribution, development, culture, and neuroscience. Format combines discussion, debate, and lecture. Offered jointly with the Graduate School of Education as H137.

title: Human Temperament
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discusses the history, classification, development, and biological characteristics of major human temperaments. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Conceptual Development: Advanced Methods Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Students participate in research on conceptual development and language acquisition. Each student has responsibility for a project. Weekly meeting to discuss assigned readings relevant to ongoing projects. Ten hours a week commitment (includes lab meeting).

title: Brain Maturation and Psychological Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discussion of current research and theory relating neural development and behavioral/cognitive change in infancy and childhood. Readings from neuroscience, comparative psychology, ethology, and cognitive psychology. Topics may include early experience and neural organization, cortical maturation and memory processes, developmental changes in attentional control, and others. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Perceptual and Attentional Development: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Advanced inquiry into current research and theory on human perceptual development and maturation of attentional processes. Topics include cross-modal perception, perception of faces and voices, contrasting theories of perception, neural plasticity, and psychophysiological indices of attention and information processing. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Core Knowledge and Cognitive Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This MIT-Harvard seminar focuses on the nature and development of human concepts by considering both infants' representations (e.g. of objects, actions, social partners) and children's inferential abilities. Discussion centers on research in human cognitive development, in relation to work in cognitive psychology, animal cognition, cognitive neuroscience, computational modeling, and philosophy. Questions include: Do humans possess innate abstract concepts of cause, agent, or belief? How do children learn new concepts, both independently and from others? The course is held every other week at MIT.

title: Psychophysiological Methods in Developmental Psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Research using physiological measures to investigate questions of development will be discussed. In particular, physiological measures used in the study of temperament, language development, developmental psychopathology, and cognitive development will be covered. Particular interests of the class will also be considered. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Perceptual and Attentional Development: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Advanced inquiry into current research and theory on human perceptual development and maturation of attentional processes. Topics include cross-modal perception, perception of faces and voices, contrasting theories of perception, neural plasticity, and psychophysiological indices of attention and information processing. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Physiological Indices of Infant Attention
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of current research on physiological responses during attentional and cognitive processing in infants. Focus on brain activity and event-related potentials, eye movements, and autonomic responsiveness.

title: Developmental Neuropsychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers advances in the understanding of behavioral development from the neuroscientific approach. Development in both perception and cognition used to evaluate the relevant contribution of intrinsic and extrinsic variables in the brain-behavior relationship. Background in behavioral and developmental neuroscience recommended.

title: Developmental Neuropsychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers advances in the understanding of behavioral development from the neuroscientific approach. Development in both perception and cognition used to evaluate the relevant contribution of intrinsic and extrinsic variables in the brain-behavior relationship. Background in behavioral and developmental neuroscience recommended.

subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers advances in the understanding of behavioral development from the neuroscientific approach. subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers advances in the understanding of behavioral development from the neuroscientific approach. title: Current Issues in Cognitive Development and Conceptual Organization
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A critical review of theories and findings in cognitive development. Focus on conceptual organization and the role of language in preschool children's thinking. Current themes in developmental research considered, e.g., constraints in knowledge acquisition, the role of access, playfulness. Readings include Piaget, Vygotsky, Carey, Keil, and others. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Developmental Neuropsychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers advances in the understanding of behavioral development from the neuroscientific approach. Development in both perception and cognition used to evaluate the relevant contribution of intrinsic and extrinsic variables in the brain-behavior relationship. Background in behavioral and developmental neuroscience recommended.

title: Cognitive Development and Music
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discusses basic and current research on the development of music cognition, with a focus on how training in music and other arts affects both specific (i.e. musical) and general (i.e., mathematical or spatial) abilities during development. Open to graduate students only.

title: Developmental Neuropsychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers advances in the understanding of behavioral development from the neuroscientific approach. Development in both perception and cognition used to evaluate the relevant contribution of intrinsic and extrinsic variables in the brain-behavior relationship. Background in behavioral and developmental neuroscience recommended.

title: Current Issues in Cognitive Development and Conceptual Organization
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A critical review of theories and findings in cognitive development. Focus on conceptual organization and the role of language in preschool children's thinking. Current themes in developmental research are considered (e.g., constraints in knowledge acquisition, the role of access, playfulness). Readings include Piaget, Vygotsky, Carey, Keil, and others. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Words, Objects, and Categories: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A current critique of the contributions of language (particularly labels) and existing knowledge (expert-novice differences; cultural differences) in the establishment of categories and concepts. Begins by examining the "linguistic determinism'' view and other arguments regarding word-concept relations. Theories and data from psycholinguistics (including ASL), anthropology, and developmental psychology.

title: Perception, Action, and Cognition in the Young Child
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Findings related to perceptual and cognitive development given a thorough analysis from a number of different perspectives. Addresses current debates in developmental psychology, including conspecifics, discontinuity in development, domain specific mechanisms, implicit versus explicit knowledge and role of action in development. Qualified undergraduates may enroll with permission of instructor. Psychology 1603 or equivalent.

title: Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course uses neuroscience methods to study the cognitive development of human infants and children. Case studies draw from research on face recognition, language, executive function, representations of objects, number and theory of mind. Science of Living Systems 20 or its predecessors and one foundational course.

title: Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course uses neuroscience methods to study the cognitive development of human infants and children. Case studies draw from research on face recognition, language, executive function, representations of objects, number and theory of mind. title: Memory Development: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines basic issues in the development of the memory system across the lifecourse. Topics include infant memory, infantile amnesia, suggestibility, affect and memory, strategy development, metamemory, memory across cultures, and the development of memory in various modalities. Considers memory in applied as well as laboratory contexts. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Social Cognitive Development: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Year-long lab course on children's social-cognitive development and the study of cooperation. Students develop and pilot experiments with children or participate in ongoing projects. In addition, students read and discuss papers on social cognition, understanding of norms, and cooperation from developmental and evolutionary psychology.

title: Social Cognitive Development: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong:
In this year-long lab-course, you will have the opportunity to participate in research on social behaviors in children. We are studying the origins of our sense of fairness, how children cooperate with others, and how they judge behaviors as moral and immoral. We take a developmental and evolutionary perspective, drawing on insights from psychology, anthropology, and primatology. You will work closely with graduate students and other senior lab members in developing experiments and running studies with children from toddlerhood into school-age. In addition to data collection, students learn how to code behavioral data via video. We also hold weekly lab-meetings to discuss ongoing projects and read the relevant literature.

Please visit our website to learn more about our research and how to join our lab: https://software.rc.fas.harvard.edu/lds/research/warneken/research/

title: Empirical and computational approaches to early cognitive development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This graduate seminar will meet once weekly to consider five topics in cognitive science that are subject to current controversies:  controversies that might be settled by a multi-pronged, interdisciplinary effort.  We will devote two meetings to each topic: for the first week, we will overview the current state of research and theory on the topic, focusing both on settled and on open questions.  For the second week, we will present and discuss student-generated (and maybe a couple of faculty-generated) approaches to addressing the questions.  Students will write response papers each week.  For the first of each pair of classes, their paper should point to one or more questions left open by the readings.  For the following class, their paper should suggest an experiment or series of experiments that might help answer some open question in the domain.  Response papers will not be graded and there is no final paper.  Students are required, however, to submit the response papers and to lead or co-lead one class discussion. Everyone should expect to participate actively in thinking through the issues.

title: Abstract Thought in Non-Human Animals, Human Infants, Young Children, and Human Adults
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A scientific account of human concepts and conceptual development must characterize the content, format, and functional roles of both the innate and the mature conceptual repertoire, as well as the developmental processes that operate on the former to produce the latter.  The evidence for innate sensory, perceptual, and motor representations is overwhelming; much recent work has provided evidence for richer primitives with content such as agent and object as well.  But the adult conceptual repertoire includes explicit abstract concepts supporting natural language, spatial symbols, mathematics and logic.  We will provide evidence for innate content in each of these domains, and explore the hypotheses that the representational systems that express that content nonetheless are qualitatively different from those that are realized in the adult state.  These issues will be explored in three case studies:  representations of number, geometry, and of logical connectives and abstract relations.  The seminar will consider proposals from linguistics, philosophy, and cognitive science concerning the combinatorial resources of natural language, and will ask whether these resources are qualitatively different from those that articulate perception and action, and if so, whether they arise in human evolution only with the evolution of language, and in human development only in the course of language acquisition.

subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Survey of theoretical debates concerning the development of concepts, reasoning, and the lexicon, including the nature of innate knowledge, continuity through development, cross-cultural and cross-species variation, and the interactions between language and thought during development. Limited to graduate students in psychology.

title: Emotional Processing
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of emotional processing, with a major focus on repression - possible origins; subsequent effects on memory, cognition, and well being; and the apparent paradox of repression, namely, beneficial psychological effects at a biological price.

title: Modularity, Domain-Specificity, and the Organization of Knowledge
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course considers the modular organization of the mind and brain, including the domains of objects, number, places, and people, based on behavioral studies of animals, humans with and without pathology, and imaging studies. The course is held every other week at MIT, and the first meeting will be Sept. 5 in Rm. NE20-461 at MIT (above the MIT Coop in Central Square; entrance is at 3 Cambridge Center, behind the Coop. If door is locked wait and someone will come down to let you in.)

title: Language and Thought
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines interrelationships between language and thought. Do different languages, learning new languages, and being multilingual affect thinking? Are some thoughts unthinkable without language? Discusses ideas from cognitive, developmental, and cultural psychology, plus linguistics, anthropology, ethology. The course is held every other week at MIT.

title: Unconscious Processing in Vision and Action
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Events that don't reach consciousness activate a smaller set of brain structures than events that do. We review psychophysical, neuropsychological and neuroimaging research that may reveal the major brain circuits and pathways involved in unconscious processing. Expected to be given in 2011$12. Undergraduate enrollment encouraged with permission of instructor. Psychology 1 or Science B-62 and a PSY 13 or MCB 80.

title: The Scientific Bases of Health Care Policy
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Five social sciences applied to health care policy. Topics: theoretical perspectives, measurement methods, research strategies, and core literature relevant to determinants of health behavior and its impacts on health service delivery. Attention to the history, politics, and social organization of medical services, and differences between individual and collective representations of health care. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Statistics and Data Analysis Through Computer Simulation

courseDescriptionLong: An inquiry-based course to evaluate data analysis techniques. Uses Monte Carlo simulation to assess strengths and limitations of formal arguments and bootstrap resampling to understand how conclusions can be derived from data. courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on current and historical issues in visual cognition. Each meeting will focus on a single topic based on articles from the primary literature. Requires some exposure to cognitive psychology or perception. Psychology 13 or equivalent and some experience reading cognitive psychology journal articles (e.g., an advanced methods course, research experience, sophomore tutorial).

title: Evolving Morality: From Primordial Soup to Superintelligent Machines (Grad. Sem. in Gen. Ed.)
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Students will help tell the story of morality on Earth, from its origins in the biology of unthinking cooperative organisms, through the psychology of intelligent cooperative primates, and into a future inhabited by machines that may be smarter and more capable than humans. Addressing longstanding philosophical questions in light of new scientific knowledge, this course will integrate material from across the humanities, social sciences, life sciences, and applied sciences with an emphasis on the development of interactive teaching tools.

title: Cognitive Evolution
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the problem of cognitive evolution, integrating current theoretical arguments from evolutionary biology, cognitive nueroscience, cognitive development, evolutionary psychology, etholgy, and the philosophy of mind. Addresses such questions as: Is language necessary for certain domains of knowledge? Are there innate concepts? What is the language of thought and can non-linguistic creatures have it? What makes humans different from other animals? How does natural selection sculpt the architecture of the mind? Open to qualified undergraduates with permission of instructors. To be considered for admission undergraduates must have taken Science B-29, have a strong background in the cognitive studies and have a working knowledge of evolutionary theory.

title: Development of Intuitive Theories: Natural Kinds, Causes, and Things that make you go hmmm ...
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the developmental origin of intuitive theories, including their structural, dynamic, and functional features. Explores how intuitive theories support the development of curiosity and children's exploration. Open only to graduate students in the Psychology Department.; all others by permission of the instructor only.

title: Psychopharmacology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Concerned with the manner in which drugs alter behavior. Includes topics such as synaptic transmission, behavioral role of specific neuromodulatory systems, pharmacological treatment of mental and neurological disorders, and computer modeling of neuromodulatory effects. Biological Sciences 25 or equivalent.

title: Advanced Topics in Psychopharmacology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The course will focus on a selection of current and historical issues in behavioral pharmacology. Weekly discussions will be focused on a single topic and will be based on readings from the literature. Open to graduate students and undergraduates who have had an exposure to psychopharmacology. Psychology 1201 or consent of instructor.

title: Categories and Concepts
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores the nature of human and non-human animal categories and concepts. We use the theoretical insights and methods from cognitive psychology, neuropsychology, philosophy, evolutionary biology, developmental psychology, and ethology to address such questions as: Do particular conceptual representations require language? How is conceptual knowledge organized in the brain? Are there innate concepts? Do animals have abstract conceptual representation? How did human conceptual representations evolve? Are conceptual representations based on features, prototypes, or theories? These questions will be explored by reviewing current papers, as well as through discussion with invited speakers. Psychology 13 or Science B-29, or permission of instructor.

title: Advanced Topics in Psychopharmacology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The course will focus on a selection of current and historical issues in behavioral pharmacology. Weekly discussions will be focused on a single topic and will be based on readings from the literature. Open to graduate students and undergraduates who have had an exposure to psychopharmacology. Psychology 1201 or consent of instructor.

title: Categories and Concepts
subject: PSY

title: Neuromodulation and Cortical Function
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Concerned with the role of neuromodulatory innervation in cortical function. Includes overview of neurophysiological effects of acetylcholine, norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin on cortical neurons, behavioral evidence on the effects of drugs influencing these modulatory systems, and computer modeling of the function of cortical networks. Biology 25 or equivalent.

title: Advanced Topics in Psychopharmacology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The course will focus on a selection of current and historical issues in behavioral pharmacology. Weekly discussions will be focused on a single topic and will be based on readings from the literature. Open to graduate students and undergraduates who have had an exposure to psychopharmacology. Psychology 1201 or consent of instructor.

title: Neuromodulation and Cortical Function
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Concerned with the role of neuromodulatory innervation in cortical function. Includes overview of neurophysiological effects of acetylcholine, norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin on cortical neurons, behavioral evidence on the effects of drugs influencing these modulatory systems, and computer modeling of the function of cortical networks. Psychology 12 or MCB 25.

title: Theory and Evidence in Cognitive Science and Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A challenge for all sciences is to determine what constitutes a reasonable argument based on the data at hand. In this seminar, we explore the kinds of assumptions and theoretical accounts offered by the practitioners of cognitive science and neuroscience. In particular, we attempt to lay bare through a case-study approach with prominent examples how the field of cognitive science/neuroscience is practiced and how arguments are developed from the existing findings. We examine such problems as the mental imagery debate, how an infant's looks tell us about its thoughts, the extent to which evolutionary theories of human thought can be tested, how neuroimaging data inform our understanding of mental representation, what inferences can be made from the study of the performance of damaged systems, the role of computational modeling in theory evaluation and development, and so on. Science B-29 and Psychology 13.

title: Neural Networks
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Overview of neural network theory, with emphasis on cortical self-organization and associative memory function. Includes survey of realistic models of olfactory cortex, hippocampus, and visual cortex.

title: Research in Language Acquisition
subject: PSY

subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines topics in neural network theory, ranging from abstract models of associative memory and feature detection, to realistic computational models of neural structures, including olfactory cortex, hippocampus, visual cortex, striatum, and retina.

title: Language and Human Nature
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Language as a window into human conceptions of space, time, causation, number, agency, sex, and status. The focus is on words and grammatical constructions, but also diverse phenomena like swearing, baby naming, and legal language. For undergraduates: Psychology 1 or Science B-62; plus one from: Psychology 13, Psychology 16, Psychology 1302, or any course in the linguistics department.

title: Evolution of Mind
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Course uses the theoretical inspiration of evolutionary biologists, along with the tools of cognitive neuroscientists, developmental psychologists, and ethologists to look at how the human mind evolved. The framework will be to place the issues squarely within different domains of knowledge (e.g., number, space, objects, language, biology, psychology) and then examine how different mental algorithms subserve such domains. Science B-29.

title: Olfactory Perception
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines olfactory perception in humans and animals. Topics include the role of olfaction in individual recognition, territoriality, and mating behavior; human olfactory discrimination; and the physiology, anatomy, and biochemistry of the olfactory system.

title: Laboratory in Auditory Cognition and Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on carrying out and interpreting research on auditory cognition and development. Students learn to critically evaluate research articles, design and conduct experiments, analyze data, and give oral presentations. Limited to undergraduate and graduate students conducting research in the instructor's laboratory.

title: Ecological Acoustics
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines acoustic information processing in a variety of vertebrate species. Topics include basic auditory system anatomy and physiology, ecological constraints on acoustic communication, and species-specific adaptations for processing biologically salient acoustic information (e.g., echolocation in bats, speech communication in humans, and sound localization in owls).

title: Auditory Information Processing and Perception: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines acoustic information processing in a variety of vertebrate species. An overview of basic auditory system physiology and psychoacoustics provides the foundation for critical review of original research articles on hearing in animals that rely primarily on acoustic information to guide behavior. Psychology 1100, Biology 25, or equivalent. Background in acoustics and advanced mathematics strongly recommended.

title: Theories of Learning
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides a tour of foundational topics in learning from a theoretical perspective. It covers a diversity of learning processes, aiming for breadth over depth (although it inevitably neglects several important forms of learning). Each meeting will consist of student-led presentations of two papers. Experience with computational modeling is not required, but students should have some familiarity with basic math (algebra and probability).

title: Individual differences and human minds: Perspectives from evolutionary psychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: What is personality?  Why are there sex differences in how we think and behave?  Where does this variance come from and what does it have to do with pathology?  In this course we will explore how individual difference can evolve as a result of natural selection, and consider how these models inform our understanding of the many ways people differ.  This course is a discussion-based seminar where students will play an active role in discussion and present weekly readings.

title: Cognitive Genetics: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discusses current research in human cognitive genetics, focusing on methodological issues. Students participate in developing ideas, materials, and protocols for research projects. Concurrent enrollment in Psychology 1305, or permission of the instructor.

title: Cognitive Genetics: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discusses current research in human cognitive genetics, focusing on methodological issues. Students participate in developing ideas, materials, and protocols for research projects. Concurrent enrollment in Psychology 1305, or permission of the instructor.

title: Cognitive Genetics: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discusses current research in human cognitive genetics, focusing on methodological issues. Students participate in developing ideas, materials, and protocols for research projects. Concurrent enrollment in Psychology 1305, or permission of the instructor.

title: Neuroethology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A close examination of neurobiological and ethological approaches to the study of species-specific behavior, such as the dance of the honeybee, echolocation of the bat, acoustic communication of the songbird, and the optomotor response of the fly. Special emphasis on the processing of biologically significant sensory information. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: The Neuroscience of Law: Can a Legal System be Grounded in Knowledge about the Brain?
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Can a legal system be based on knowledge of the brain? Discusses implications of neuroscience on the characterization of human nature, the relation between genes, brain, and social interactions, and determination of right vs. wrong. Preference given to upper-level undergraduates and to graduate students. Offered jointly with the Law School as 44041-31.

title: The Neuroscience of Law: Can a Legal System be Grounded in Knowledge about the Brain?
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Can a legal system be based on knowledge of the brain? Discusses implications of neuroscience on the characterization of human nature, the relation between genes, brain, and social interactions, and determination of right vs. wrong. Preference given to upper-level undergraduates and to graduate students. Offered jointly with the Law School as 44041-31.

title: Brain Mystery: What is so special about the primate parietal cortex?
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Read and discuss papers to understand how the primate parietal cortex supports a wide range of cognitive operations, including attention, visual short-term memory, number representation, episodic memory retrieval, decision making and motor planning. SLS-20 or its predecessors and either PSY 13, PSY 14, or MCB 80.

title: The Neuroscience of Law: Can a Legal System be Grounded in Knowledge about the Brain?
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Can a legal system be based on knowledge of the brain? Discusses implications of neuroscience on the characterization of human nature, the relation between genes, brain, and social interactions, and determination of right vs. wrong. Preference given to upper-level undergraduates and to graduate students. Offered jointly with the Law School as 44041-31.

title: Neuroethology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A close examination of neurobiological and ethological approaches to the study of species-specific behavior, such as the dance of the honeybee, echolocation of the bat, acoustic communication of the songbird, and the optomotor response of the fly. Special emphasis on the processing of biologically significant sensory information. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Brain Mystery: What is so Special about the Primate Frontal Cortex
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Read and discuss papers to understand how the primate frontal cortex supports a wide range of cognitive operations, including attention, working memory, executive control functions, and decision making. Advanced graduate course not open to undergraduates. This course will only be given in spring 2014 and will not be offered again.

title: Brain Mystery: What is so Special about the Primate Frontal Cortex
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Read and discuss papers to understand how the primate frontal cortex supports a wide range of cognitive operations, including attention, working memory, executive control functions, and decision making. Advanced graduate course not open to undergraduates. This course will only be given in spring 2014 and will not be offered again.

title: The Neuroscience of Law: Can a Legal System be Grounded in Knowledge about the Brain?
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Can a legal system be based on knowledge of the brain? Discusses implications of neuroscience on the characterization of human nature, the relation between genes, brain, and social interactions, and determination of right vs. wrong. Preference given to upper-level undergraduates and to graduate students. Offered jointly with the Law School as 44041-31.

title: Object Representation in the Mind and Brain
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How does our visual system translate complex arrays of visual inputs into meaningful objects that we can act upon? What do we need to construct a sound theory of object representation? What progress have researchers made in understanding this process over the past few decades? What information is essential and where is it computed and represented in the human brain? In this seminar, we will address these questions by reading and discussing key papers on object representation, critically evaluating results from behavioral, neurophysiological, neuropsychological, special population (e.g., blind individuals), neuroimaging, and computational studies. This seminar will not only provide a critical review of the current literature, but also identify important challenges that await future research.

title: Animal Sonar Systems: Neural and Perceptual Processes
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review and discussion of current research topics on acoustic imaging by sonar. An in-depth assessment of perceptual, neural, and theoretical studies of echolocation in bats and marine mammals. Open to upper-level undergraduates with permission of instructor. Psychology 1100 or Biology 25 or equivalent.

title: Applying fMRI to Cognitive Research
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Covers basic fMRI methods in cognitive neuroscience. It takes the user and the reader's perspectives. Topics include data collection and analysis, experimental design, and the connection between BOLD and neuronal activity. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Current Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Papers reporting recent research in cognitive neuroscience read and discussed. Topics include visual deficits (including deficits in reading and failure to recognize faces), language deficits, and memory deficits. Either Psychology 1110, 1175, or equivalent, and some neuropsychology, neuroanatomy, or neurobiology.

title: Current Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Papers reporting recent research in cognitive neuroscience are read and discussed. Topics include visual and cognitive deficit following brain damage and disease and the relation between cognition and emotion. Either Psychology 13, or equivalent, and some neuropsychology, neuroanatomy, or neurobiology.

title: Cognitive Psychology and Neuroscience: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Covers basic research skills (experimental design, programming, statistics) in studies on attention and memory. In addition to guided readings, students conduct a research project and write an APA-style article on it. Open to undergraduate students with permission of the instructor.

title: Current Issues in Human and Machine Vision
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A review of recent papers in human and machine vision and in the physiology of the visual system. Topics include early vision, multiple pathways in vision, effects of attention in early vision, 3-D inference, and pattern recognition. Open to advanced undergraduates.

title: Topics in Cognitive Neuropsychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Current developments in various domains of cognitive neuropsychology are reviewed. Topics include the various forms of aphasia, dyslexia, agraphia, anomia, agnosia, and visual neglect. Specific topics vary from year to year.

title: Topics in Cognitive Neuropsychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Current developments in various domains of cognitive neuropsychology are reviewed. Topics include the various forms of aphasia, dyslexia, agraphia, anomia, agnosia, and visual neglect. Specific topics vary from year to year.

subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores how empirical findings and theoretical positions in the area of visual cognition elucidate how the mind and brain work. PSY 1 or Sci B-62 plus either PSY 13 or MCB 80

subject: PSY

title: Topics in Language Research: Linguistic, Cognitive, and Neural Aspects
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on recent issues in language processing. Research findings from various areas and different approaches are considered, including neuroimaging studies, cross-linguistic investigations, aphasia research, and bilingualism. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Attention and Memory
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines theory and research on selective attention, short-term memory search and retrieval, "mental chronometrics,'' capacity limitations, and resource allocation.

title: Laboratory in Cognitive Neuropsychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Patterns of perceptual and cognitive impairments resulting from brain damage are used to inform theories of normal cognitive functioning. Students learn to design experiments for testing brain-damaged subjects, and to analyze, interpret, and present results.

title: Laboratory in Cognitive Neuropsychology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Patterns of linguistic, perceptual, and cognitive impairments resulting from brain damage used to inform theories of normal cognitive functioning. Students learn to design experiments for testing brain-damaged subjects, and to analyze, interpret, and present results.

subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Patterns of perceptual and cognitive impairments resulting from brain damage are used to inform theories of normal cognitive functioning. Students learn to design experiments for testing brain-damaged subjects, and to analyze, interpret, and present results.

title: Current Topics in Cognitive Neuroscience Research
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Discussion of current research and didactic lecture on technical aspects of methods in cognitive neuroscience research. Readings cover specific research programs based on both animal models and human studies of memory and executive function. Limited to students involved in research. Previous background in cognitive neuroscience required.

title: Memory and Amnesia: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines memory and amnesia from cognitive, neuropsychological, and psychobiological perspectives. Focuses on the relationship between memory/amnesia at the level of the individual and memory/amnesia at the level of society. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Memory and Amnesia
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines memory and amnesia from cognitive, neuropsychological, and psychobiological perspectives. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Memory and Amnesia
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines memory and amnesia from cognitive, neuropsychological, and psychobiological perspectives. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Memory and Amnesia
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines memory and amnesia from cognitive, neuropsychological, and psychobiological perspectives. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Memory and Amnesia: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines memory and amnesia from cognitive, neuropsychological, evolutionary, and psychobiological perspectives. Focuses on theidea that memory problems can be divided into seven fundamental types: transcience, absent-mindedness, blocking, misattribution, suggestibility, bias, and persistence. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Laboratory on Reinforcement Learning and Decision Making
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This lab course provides instruction and experience in conducting research on reinforcement learning and decision making, using a combination of computational, behavioral and neural techniques. Students will learn how to fit models of reinforcement learning and decision making to behavioral data, collect and analyze functional MRI data, and develop algorithms for artificial intelligence. Open to graduate and undergraduate students working in the instructor’s laboratory. Undergraduates are required to write a research report at the end of the semester on the studies conducted in the lab.

title: Construction and Function of Memory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: What is memory for? We examine issues of memory structure in light of questions concerning memory function, including errors and distortions and the ways memory informs decisions about future reactions. For psychology concentrators: Science of Living Systems 20 and one course from PSY 13, PSY 14, PSY 15, PSY 18, or SLS 15; or permission of instructors.

title: Case Studies of Cognitive and Neural Models
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: What makes a successful cognitive or neural model? In this seminar, we will do a series of in depth case studies to address this question, exploring several of the more successful cognitive and neural models. While many examples will be drawn from the literature on human vision, the course will also draw on examples from language, development, and higher-level reasoning. Science of Living Systems 20 or its predecessors plus Psychology 13 or Psychology 14 or MCB 80, or permission of instructor.

title: Advanced Laboratory in Cognitive Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Students work directly on a research project and get hands-on experience with neuroimaging and cognitive neuroscience techniques, including functional MRI. MRI laboratory training consists of safety, instruction on running the scanner, and paradigm design. In addition to laboratory work, students attend a weekly research seminar where ongoing and proposed research projects are discusses.

title: Laboratory on Cognitive and Neural Organization
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This lab course provides instruction and experience in conducting research on cognitive architecture and neural organization, via the methods of visual cognition and cognitive neuroscience. Special focus on issues of high-level visual representation and the corresponding structure in neural response profiles.  Open to graduate and undergraduate students working in the instructor’s laboratory. Undergraduates are required to write research report at the end of the semester on the studies conducted in the lab.

title: Laboratory in Cognitive Neuroscience: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on how to do research on visual cognition and related topics. Students learn to conduct experiments, including fundamentals of experimental design and data analysis. Concludes with formal written report and presentation of research. Meets laboratory methods requirement for honors undergraduates. Open to undergraduates only if they've met the following prerequisites and have permission of the instructor: Psychology 1; Psychology 13 or Psychology 1352 or MCB 80; and Statistics.

title: Laboratory in Cognitive Neuroscience: Seminar

title: Laboratory in Cognitive Neuroscience: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on how one asks and answers questions about visual cognition. Students formally present their research to the seminar as well as work independently.

title: Laboratory on Cognitive and Neural Organization
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This lab course provides instruction and experience in conducting research on cognitive architecture and neural organization, via the methods of visual cognition and cognitive neuroscience. Special focus on issues of high-level visual representation and the corresponding structure in neural response profiles.  Open to graduate and undergraduate students working in the instructor’s laboratory. Undergraduates are required to write research report at the end of the semester on the studies conducted in the lab.

subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Open to graduate and undergraduate students working in the instructor's laboratory. For information on joining this lab, please contact Prof. Xu at yaodaxu@fas.harvard.edu

title: Conceptual Development: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Covers research methods for the study of conceptual development throughout the life span. All students must be currently engaged in experimental research. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Conceptual Development: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Covers research methods for the study of conceptual development throughout the life span. All students must be currently engaged in experimental research. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Visual Processes: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Targets articles in motion, stereo, color, texture, linear systems analysis, visual attention, surface representation, and object recognition.

title: Visual Processes: Eye Movements, Vision, and Visual Attention: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of target articles on the control of eye movements, the characteristics of the visual system that could be affected by eye movements, and related aspects of visual perception and visual attention.

title: Conceptual Development: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Covers research methods for the study of conceptual development throughout the life span. All students must be currently engaged in experimental research. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Visual Processes: Perceptual Learning: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of target articles on early learning in the visual system: long-lasting effects of extended training on perception. Class participation required.

title: Functional Imaging of the Visual System: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review of target articles on the neuroanatomy of the visual system, based on findings from PET, fMRI, MEG, and other neuroimaging techniques. Class participation required. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Varieties of Attention
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative survey of writings on attention from Ibn Al-Haytham to James to selected modern views. We will consider whether and how their heterogeneous views on the mechanisms and roles of attention fit together. Students will research historical sources and present target articles in these areas. Class participation required.

title: Current topics in cognitive neuroscience of vision and cognition
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: In this seminar, we will learn about current developments in vision and cognitive neuroscience research. Based on the students’ research interests, we will select appropriate papers that will cover the background and ongoing research effort on particular research topics, including, but not limited to, attention, working memory, and object representation. We will discuss research papers using behavioral, human neuroimging and monkey neurophysiology methods. Students will also present their own ongoing work relevant to the research topics under discussion.

title: Laboratory for Computational Cognitive Science and Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The lab course provides instruction and experience in conducting research on computational cognitive science, with an emphasis on cognitive development and program induction. Open to graduate and undergraduate students working in the instructor’s laboratory. Undergraduates are required to write research report at the end of the semester on the studies in the lab.

title: Laboratory for Computational Cognitive Science and Development
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: The lab course provides instruction and experience in conducting research on computational cognitive science, with an emphasis on cognitive development and program induction. Open to graduate and undergraduate students working in the instructor’s laboratory. Undergraduates are required to write research report at the end of the semester on the studies in the lab.

title: The Development of Social Cognition
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How do children create representations of their social world? Important topics in social cognitive development (e.g., social categorization, in-group preference) are explored from the vantage point of current theories of conceptual representations and their development. Open to graduate students and undergraduate students by permission of instructors. Psychology 16, or Psychology 15, or equivalent courses.

title: The Development of Social Cognition
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How do children create representations of their social world? Important topics in social cognitive development (e.g., social categorization, in-group preference) are explored from the vantage point of current theories of conceptual representations and their development. Open to graduate students and undergraduate students by permission of instructors. Psychology 16, or Psychology 15, or equivalent courses.

title: The Development of Social Cognition
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How do children create representations of their social world? Important topics in social cognitive development (e.g., social categorization, in-group preference) are explored from the vantage point of current theories of conceptual representations and their development. Open to graduate students and undergraduate students by permission of instructors. Psychology 16, or Psychology 15, or equivalent courses.

title: Topics in Cognitive Science: Differences Among Readers
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the similarities and differences among different populations of readers. Topics include developmental dyslexia, reading impairment due to brain damage, adult and child language acquisition, bilingual readers, and individual differences in basic cognitive skills. Considers the implications for both basic cognitive theories and educational and remedial programs. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: The Development of Social Cognition
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How do children create representations of their social world? Important topics in social cognitive development (e.g., social categorization, in-group preference) are explored from the vantage point of current theories of conceptual representations and their development. Open to graduate students and undergraduate students by permission of instructors. Psychology 16, or Psychology 15, or equivalent courses.

title: Topics in Cognitive Science: Memory in Networks and Brains
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Cognitive, neural, and connectionist models of learning and memory, with an emphasis on the role of the hippocampal system in human memory. Topics include learning and forgetting in connectionist networks; implicit and explicit memory; preserved learning in amnesia; memory impairments due to aging; neural models of hippocampal structure and function. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Topics in Cognitive Science: Memory in Networks and Brains
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Cognitive, neural, and connectionist models of learning and memory, with an emphasis on the role of the hippocampal system in human memory. Topics include learning and forgetting in connectionist networks; implicit and explicit memory; preserved learning in amnesia; memory impairments due to aging; neural models of hippocampal structure and function. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Speech Processing by Humans and Computers
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers human and computer recognition of spoken language. Focus on the nature of speech signals, specialized mental processes for speech perception, integration of knowledge sources, and architecture of artificial intelligence systems. Some background in cognitive psychology, artificial intelligence, or acoustic phonetics desirable.

title: Theory and Evidence in Cognitive Science and Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores how Cognitive Science and Neuroscience work from findings to theoretical positions. Examines mirror neurons in mental simulation; domain-specific vs. expertise systems of knowledge; how neuroimaging and patient data inform understanding of mental representation PSY 13 or MCB 80.

title: Speech Processing by Humans and Computers
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers human and computer recognition of spoken language. Focus on the nature of speech signals, specialized mental processes for speech perception, integration of knowledge sources, and architecture of artificial intelligence systems. Some background in cognitive psychology, artificial intelligence, or acoustic phonetics desirable.

title: Speech Processing by Humans and Computers
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Considers human and computer recognition of spoken language. Focus on the nature of speech signals, specialized mental processes for speech perception, integration of knowledge sources, and architecture of artificial intelligence systems. Some background in cognitive psychology, artificial intelligence, or acoustic phonetics desirable.

title: Theory and Evidence in Cognitive Science and Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores how Cognitive Science and Neuroscience work from findings to theoretical positions. Examines mirror neurons in mental simulation; domain-specific vs. expertise systems of knowledge; how neuroimaging and patient data inform understanding of mental representation PSY 13 or MCB 80.

title: Hot Topics in Cognitive Science and Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Explores how research with different methods (behavior, neuroimaging, neurophysiology) and populations can be integrated to understand mental representations and their neural organization. Topics include representations of objects, actions and words, language and social decision-making. Expected to be given in 2011$12. Undergraduates welcome with permission of instructor. Psychology 13 or MCB 80.

title: Hot Topics in Cognitive Science and Neuroscience
subject: PSY

title: Individual Differences and Public Policy
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How and why do human beings differ in socially significant ways? A consideration of the methods and findings of differential psychology and behavior genetics in relation to cognitive abilities and personality. Correlations between these dimensions of individual variation and population growth, worker productivity, crime rates, and other topics as selected by members of the seminar.

subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: How and why do human beings differ in socially significant ways? A consideration of the methods and findings of differential psychology and behavior genetics in relation to cognitive abilities and personality. Correlations between these dimensions of individual variation and population growth, worker productivity, crime rates, and other topics as selected by seminar members.

subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Involves readings, seminar discussion, and research on emotional disorders conducted in the instructor's laboratory (e.g., social anxiety disorder, complicated grief, obsessive-compulsive disorder).

title: Cognitive-Behavioral Treatment of Psychological Disorders
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Covers current cognitive-behavioral approaches to the treatment of common psychological disorders in adults. Emphasis is on the practical aspects of treatment, and on treatment outcome research. Includes theoretical underpinnings of cognitive-behavioral therapy. Limited to Harvard graduate students in clinical psychology.

title: Cultural and Individual Diversity
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines cultural, racial, ethnic, and other individual differences in human behavior which affect the practice of psychology. Reviews current science examining the relations between these factors and human behavior, psychopathology, and provision of psychological services.

title: Cultural and Individual Diversity
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines cultural, racial, ethnic, and other individual differences in human behavior which affect the practice of psychology. Reviews current science examining the relations between these factors and human behavior, psychopathology, and provision of psychological services.

title: Cultural, Racial, and Ethnic Bases of Behavior
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines cultural, racial, ethnic, and other individual differences in human behavior which affect the practice of psychology. Reviews current science examining the relations between these factors and human behavior, psychopathology, and provision of psychological services. Enrollment limited to doctoral students.

title: Motivation: Neuropsychology and Functional Neurochemistry
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Four somewhat separate neuropsychological systems provide the material basis for human motivation. These systems govern response to punishment and threat, negatively, and consummatory and incentive reward, positively. Each system differs structurally, and neurochemically. The processes we term ^'^'cognition'' and ^'^'emotion'' constitute means to regulate and express or signal motivational states, respectively. We will attempt to provisionally map the neuropsychological circuitry underlying motivation, and to consider the implications of that map for comprehension of drug and alcohol abuse, affiliative bonding, psychopathology, and social conflict.

title: Aspects of Identity and Self: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines historical, cultural, and developmental aspects of self and identity. Topics include self-esteem, states of self-awareness, and clarity and stability of the self-concept. The measurement of self-concept transitions and the influence of physical attractiveness on identity are also considered. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of the instructor.

title: Social Identity and Information Processing Theory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines relationship between social identity, information processing, and regulation of emotion. Describes role narrative plays in construction of such identity. Discusses emotional, cognitive, and behavioral consequences of identity disruption. Sources include A. R. Luria, J. A. Gray, C. G. Jung. Open to seniors with permission of instructor.

title: Laboratory in Eating Disorders
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Trains students in the assessment of eating disorders, including anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge eating disorder, etc. Differentiation between normal and abnormal behaviors. Psychometric properties of various self-report and structured interview assessments covered. Psychology 1, Psychology 18, and introductory statistics.

title: Social Identity, Social Conflict, and Information Processing Theory: Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Topic: subjective motivation for participation in group conflict. Examines relationship between social identity, information processing, and regulation of emotion. Describes role myth plays in construction of such identity. Discusses emotional, cognitive, and behavioral consequences of identity disruption. Sources include A. R. Luria, J. A. Gray, C. G. Jung. Open to undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Laboratory in Eating Disorders
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Trains students in the assessment of eating disorders, including anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge eating disorder, and eating disorders not otherwise specified. Particular attention given to differentiating between normal and abnormal eating and weight control behaviors. Psychometric properties of various self-report and structured interview assessments covered. Psychology 1, Psychology 18, and introductory statistics.

subject: PSY

title: Schizotypy and the Schizophrenia Spectrum
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Advanced graduate seminar that explores, in depth, the origins and development of the schizophrenia-spectrum concept as well as models of schizotypy and schizophrenia liability. Emphasis is on the integration of theoretical models with available empirical data from multiple vantage points including phenomenology, cognition, neuropsychology, neurobiology, and genetics. Mathematical approaches to model testing will also be covered.

title: Emotional Processing
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines models of emotion and emotional processing and the influence of emotion on biological processes, memory, and adjustment. Topics include bereavement, repression, post-traumatic stress disorder, anger, anxiety, depression, disturbed affect in schizophrenia, emotion and health, and the role of emotion in therapeutic change.

title: Schizotypy and the Schizophrenia Spectrum
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Advanced graduate seminar that explores, in depth, the origins and development of the schizophrenia-spectrum concept as well as models of schizotypy and schizophrenia liability. Emphasis is on the integration of theoretical models with available empirical data from multiple vantage points including phenomenology, cognition, neuropsychology, neurobiology, and genetics. Mathematical approaches to model testing will also be covered.

title: Schizotypy and the Schizophrenia Spectrum
subject: PSY

Emphasis is on the integration of theoretical models with available empirical data from multiple vantage points including phenomenology, cognition, neuropsychology, neurobiology, and genetics. mathematical approaches to model testing will also be covered.

title: Cognition and Anxiety: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Students gain laboratory experience conducting research on cognitive functioning in subjects with anxiety disorders or histories of trauma.Students may test subjects, score data protocols, learn about data analysis, and read articles in the area. Psychology 18 recommended but not required.

title: Cognition and Anxiety: Research Seminar
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Students gain laboratory experience conducting research on cognitive functioning in subjects with anxiety disorders or histories of trauma.Students may test subjects, score data protocols, learn about data analysis, and read articles in the area. Psychology 18 recommended but not required.

title: Clinical Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Provides a comprehensive review of neuroscientific approaches to understanding key biological systems involved in various forms of psychopathology. Implications for treatment and diagnosis will be emphasized. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor. Psychology 18 or MCB 80.

title: Clinical Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Provides a comprehensive review of neuroscientific approaches to understanding key biological systems involved in various forms of psychopathology. title: Laboratory in Development and Psychopathology
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Provides instruction and experience conducting clinical research in laboratory settings with children and adolescents, with a particular focus on understanding the role that experiences of stress and adversity play in shaping children's emotional, cognitive, and brain development in ways that place them at risk for experiencing psychopathology.

title: Laboratory in Development and Psychopathology

courseDescriptionLong: Provides instruction and experience conducting clinical research in laboratory settings with children and adolescents, with a particular focus on understanding the role that experiences of stress and adversity play in shaping children's emotional, cognitive, and brain development in ways that place them at risk for experiencing psychopathology.

title: Psychological Treatment Research
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review theories of behavior change, methods of studying such change (single-case research designs, randomized clinical trials, etc.), and current evidence-based approaches to assessing and treating psychopathology. Examines historical, ethical, and cultural issues.

title: Psychological Treatment Research
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Review theories of behavior change, methods of studying such change (single-case research designs, randomized clinical trials, etc.), and current evidence-based approaches to assessing and treating psychopathology. title: Affective and Social Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Reviews two emerging fields in neuroscience, affective and social neuroscience. Through integration of human and animal data, the course focuses on mapping affect, motivation, and social cognition to brain function. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor. Psychology 1 or Science B-62 plus any Tier 2 course.

title: Affective and Social Neuroscience
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Two emerging fields in neuroscience, affective and social neuroscience, will be reviewed. Through integration of human and animal data, the course will focus on mapping affect, motivation, and social cognition to brain function. Open to graduate students and advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Mood Disorders
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines history and current status of research and theory concerning major mood disorders (i.e., major depression and bipolar disorder). Topics include: conceptualization and classification, diagnostic criteria and procedures, research methods, theoretical models of etiology and treatment, normative patterns in the course(s) of mood disorders, factors empirically related to relapse rates, and their implications for models of etiology and treatment. Psychology 1240.

title: Psychology of Racism, Prejudice, and Discrimination
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course provides an in-depth and comprehensive exposure to the theoretical and methodological issues within the social psychology of racism and prejudice research. Approaches will include sociology, political science, and anthropology.

title: Psychopathology of Delusions
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the psychology of belief formation and the development of delusions. Theory, method, and data from clinical and experimental investigations are presented. Open to advanced undergraduates with permission of instructor.

title: Diagnostic Interviewing
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Students develop clinical interviewing and diagnostic skills using the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-III-R and other instruments. Examines issues in diagnosis and assessment; provides exposure to psychopathology syndromes via tapes and clinical interviews.

title: Diagnostic Interviewing
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: This course is designed to provide students who already have a good working knowledge of psychopathology, with specific interviewing and diagnostic skills. Issues in psychiatric diagnosis will be discussed and particular attention will be devoted to the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM (SCID-5). We will focus on the SCID-5, with some exposure to other structured interviews (e.g. K-SADS). Diagnostic interviewing techniques will be illustrated using video examples and in-class role-plays will be utilized for diagnostic assessment practice. The aim of the course is to provide students with the skills needed to make reliable diagnostic assessments for research and clinical purposes.

title: Diagnostic Interviewing
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the development of clinical interviewing and diagnostic skills through exposure to the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-III-R (SCID-R) and other research-oriented diagnostic interviews. Examines the major issues in diagnosis and assessment and provides exposure to syndromes of psychopathology via videotapes and audiotapes. Psychology 18.

title: Diagnostic Interviewing: Practicum
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Supervised experience in psychiatric diagnosis. Students assess Axis I and Axis II disorders in clinical samples. Students are required to travel to practicum sites to conduct interviews between class meetings. Graduate students only. Psychology 2040 and Psychology 2460 strictly required.

title: Diagnostic Interviewing: Practicum
subject: PSY
courseDescriptionLong: Offers students who have completed Psychology 2460 supervised experience in psychiatric diagnosis. Students will assess Axis I and Axis II disorders in clinical and non-clinical samples. Students will be required to travel to practicum site(s) to conduct interviews between class meetings. Psychology 18 and Psychology 2460.
